Title: Zero loads: Canceling load requests by tracking zero values
Source title: Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques - Conference Proceedings, PACT
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE 412 96, Goteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Islam, M.Md., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE 412 96, Goteborg, Sweden; Stenstrom, P., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, SE 412 96, Goteborg, Sweden
Abstract: The considerable gap between processor and DRAM speed and the power losses in the cache hierarchy calls for more efficient approaches. Broadly speaking, cache-hierarchy efficiency can be increased either by improving cache management or by reducing the number of load instructions that reach the cache hierarchy. We introduce the notion of zero loads to approach the latter. This paper explores the potential of tracking locations that contain the value 'zero'. Loads directed to such locations - termed Zero Loads - can be cancelled before they are issued in the cache hierarchy. We find that as many as 21% of the loads are Zero Loads and about one third of them are critical, i.e., ends up on the critical memory path for out-of-order cores. Motivated by this observation, we explore two innovative structures to capture Zero Loads by essentially book-keeping earlier visited blocks/locations that return 'zero'. These schemes are shown to be capable of improving performance and power/energy efficiency considerably. Copyright 2008 ACM.
Author Keywords: cache; load criticality; prediction; value locality; zero load

Title: Modified carbon matrix - High energy anode for lithium ion battery
Affiliations: Institute of Electrochemistry and Energy Systems, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Acad. G. Bonchev St., 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Trifonova, A.V., Institute of Electrochemistry and Energy Systems, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Acad. G. Bonchev St., 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The recent commercial applications for packaged electrical power emphasize the need for high performance Li-ion battery systems and require the development of new alternative electrode materials, especially negative, which exceed the capabilities of conventional ones in terms of energy density. Graphites are the standard materials used as anode in lithium-ion systems. They have good compatibility with most electrolyte solvents and stable capacity over several hundreds of cycles but it is limited of 372 Ah/kg and rather low compared to the increasingly investigated lithium inserting metals and alloys (such as Al, Sn, Si, SnSb). Based on these facts, different modifications of graphite such as mild oxidation, coating by polymers and other kinds of carbon, composite formation, etc. are also the research activities focus of many scientific groups. This paper will provide an overview about different graphite modification methods. The concepts for the creation of lithium storage hosts with improved cycling performance will be highlighted. © 2008 Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Union of Chemists in Bulgaria.
Author Keywords: Carbon matrix; High-energy anodes; Li-ion batteries; Modification methods

Title: Size effects and nanostructured materials for energy applications
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering and Engineering Science Programme, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117574, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Balaya, P., Department of Mechanical Engineering and Engineering Science Programme, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117574, Singapore
Abstract: Size reduction in nanocrystals leads to a variety of exciting phenomena due to enhanced surface-to-volume ratio and reduced transport length for the mobile charges. We consider some of these anomalous phenomena restricting our discussions to the effects of nano-size on energetics and transport behaviour, with a few examples to illustrate materials challenges for efficient energy conversion and storage. We show that nano-size affects the thermodynamical aspects due to excess surface contributions giving rise to enhanced cell voltage in lithium batteries. An anomalous electrical conduction occurs at nano-size, its relevance is briefly highlighted in the context of energy conversion using fuel cells and excitonic solar cells. The benefit of narrowly spaced interfaces also results in rapid energy storage due to the reduction of the effective diffusion path. Thus, in the context of storage behaviour, nanocrystalline electrodes exhibit high capacity as well as Coulombic efficiency and in some cases high rate performance. An interfacial lithium storage mechanism which is a consequence of nanocrystallinity has been discussed to explain the extra storage when metal is brought in contact with Li2O/LiF at nanosize. Superior storage performance by supercapacitors and efficient waste heat conversion by thermoelectric devices using nanostructured materials are also briefly highlighted. This review thus emphasises fundamental understanding and novel concepts at nano-size for the development of excellent materials which achieve efficient energy conversion and storage, both of which are vital in facing the challenges posed by global warming and the predicted future limited energy resources. © 2008 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

Authors: Nadau L., Chevallier V., Pichayrou O.
Title: A thermodynamical simulation tool for gas storage management in a salt cavity
Affiliations: GDF SUEZ
Authors with affiliations: Nadau, L., GDF SUEZ; Chevallier, V., GDF SUEZ; Pichayrou, O., GDF SUEZ
Abstract: The amounts of gas provided by producing countries are almost constant throughout the year, whereas gas consumption highly depends on climate conditions. For example the consumption is five times greater in January than in August. In order to adjust the natural gas ressources to the fluctuating consumption, gas companies store gas underground: the surplus of natural gas received in the summer must be stored so that it can be available when the weather turns cold in the winter. Two techniques of gas storage are used in France: Aquifer storages have large gas capacities Salt storages are used for their high performance. They can react quickly to fluctuations in consumption (in emergency situations or during unexpected short term demand surges) Furthermore, since the European energy market liberalization (in 2000 and 2007), new gas storage uses have appeared. Indeed, the period and the reason of gas use have been modified which has led to increase the number of injection and withdrawal movements during the year. Moreover, the European legislation imposes on storage operators to publish precisely their gas storage capacities. Mainly due to these reasons, GDF SUEZ group is developing the software SITHERGAZ. This software can simulate the daily salt cavity operation and gives the thermodynamical behaviour of the cavity. This behaviour is strongly depending on the process thermal historic. In order to achieve this goal, it is necessary to take into account the leaching and the dewatering phases as pre-processors. Moreover, the creep effect needs a careful attention since it strongly affects the results. Finally, the need of short time computation is important in order to be useful for the salt cavity storage operators. In this article, we present the constitutive models of SITHERGAZ, the numerical methods employed and finally a comparison between numerical results and measurements from a GDF SUEZ cavity. We show that numerical results closely match in field measurements. However because of the leaching techniques developed by GDF SUEZ, we emphasise that the cavity used for the measurements is in good agreement with the geometrical conditions required by the models.

Title: Natural gas industry in Iran
Affiliations: Research and Technology Dept., National Iranian Gas Company, No.77-Southern Aban St. - Karimkhan Ave., Tehran-1598753113, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Omidvar, H., Research and Technology Dept., National Iranian Gas Company, No.77-Southern Aban St. - Karimkhan Ave., Tehran-1598753113, Iran
Abstract: AT the end of March 2007, the remaining quantity of recoverable gas reserves in the country has been in excess of 28.3 trillion cubic meters that is the second gas rich country in the word. While the geological studies in certain geographical regions of the country have not been thoroughly conducted yet. it is likely to explore further reserves of gas in the future. Therefore a thorough and explicit planning knowledge is essential for utilization of this energy carrier. Iran is one of the largest gas rich countries in the world that production potentials exceed gas injection and domestic consumption requirements. Gas can be utilized as feedstock for petrochemical and refining products or exported through pipelines or as LNG. By injecting gas into oil reservoirs while increasing the oil recovery ratio of oil fields, gas storage from production of shared reservoirs into non- shared reservoirs is as well accomplished. Gas consumption in domestic markets and its substitution with oil products in addition to environmental benefits, will also result into the optimum consumption of these products and relieve the government from the heavy burden of existing subsidies and the heavy expenditures of importing these products into the country. To supply gas requirements, proper operation and appropriate production of shared reservoirs such as south pars with the objective of securing gas requirements and providing balance of supply and demand as well as utilization of maximum share in these reservoirs are other essentials towards development of this vital industry. Several energy experts and Iran's economy analysts believe that further expansion and utilization of natural gas is an essential element for sustainable development and this energy carrier is considered the superior fuel of the 21 century. According to reliable estimations, natural gas in regard to its intrinsic characteristics and especially environmental suitability is one of the energy carriers that will attain the highest growth rate among other energy carriers with in the next two decades which itself is indicative for consumption growth of this substance in the global basket of energy consumption. The need of the world's countries for energy sources along the enormous natural gas reserves in the country opens broad economical, political dialogue scene towards us and contributes an outstanding strategic significance to our gas resources. Iran, regard to her geographical and political strategic situation. Can play a leading role in global gas supply and act as a bridge between the enormous Middle Eastern gas reserves with major gas consumption and demand centers in Europe and Asia Planning and policy making regarding the development of gas industry, it is essential to manage all aspects of gas from exploration and production to consumption, injection and exports and etc. is essential to be administered by the national Iranian gas company so that prepared plans could be implemented without being subject to such problems as lack of coordination, parallel activities and organizational difficulties. The Islamic republic of Iran having access to enormous quantities of gas reserves, towards attaining the appropriate disposition in regard to her volume of reserves should as well furnish the provision of absorbing the world's up to date technological capital, to compensate her remoteness from worlds gas markets. The 21 century is the century of gas and our country potentially and in an exceptional manner, by adopting an organized strategy ,could portray the most natural and influential role for the people and the country's economy as well as in the region and the world. The increasing global needs for hydrocarbon energies and related industries / encompasses one of the golden opportunities for our country. In conclusion it is worth mentioning that within that the next 10 years Iran requires capital investment in excess of $50 billion in her gas industry to become capable of accomplishing objectives such as supply of domestic demands/provide the necessary gas for injection to oil wells / increase gas reservoirs/added value through transaction with industries and to realize proper disposition in regional and global gas market.

Authors: Näslund M., De Wit J., Madsen L.G., Karlsen M.L.
Title: Residential fuel cell micro cogeneration - Opportunities and challenges in the system design
Affiliations: Danish Gas Technology Centre, DGC, Denmark; IRD Fuel Cells; Dantherm Power
Authors with affiliations: Näslund, M., Danish Gas Technology Centre, DGC, Denmark; De Wit, J., Danish Gas Technology Centre, DGC, Denmark; Madsen, L.G., IRD Fuel Cells; Karlsen, M.L., Dantherm Power
Abstract: There is great interest in gas-fired micro cogeneration, and it is one way to reduce the overall energy consumption. It is also a possible way for the gas distribution companies to retain customers when the heating demand decreases due to improved heat insulation and better appliance efficiency. The micro-cogeneration system considered in this paper consists of a fuel cell unit, heat storage, a supplementary boiler and a control system. The full advantages and characteristics of the system can only be evaluated and compared to other solutions when the entire system is considered. The current Danish program for residential cogeneration units based on fuel cells is used as example of approaches and results are presented. Heat losses and electricity consumption are used as an example of the necessity to consider the entire heating system. The Danish demonstration program is based on earlier fuel cell basic research. Three fuel cell technologies are developed for residential micro-cogeneration purposes. The three technologies are low-temperature PEM, high-temperature PEM and SOFC. The output is 1.0-1.5 kWe. Both natural gas and hydrogen are considered as fuels. The progress for the technologies is briefly described.

Title: Solar City: Reconnecting Energy Generation and Use to the Technical and Social Logic of Solar Energy
Authors with affiliations: Scheer, H.
Abstract: The determining factor of an energy system is the energy sources it makes available. All subsequent steps follow on from this choice: the energy conversion technologies and infrastructure required for its optimal use, and the energy habits, social opportunities, and types of business, as well as the settlement and transport structures which result from it. With the evolution of very densely populated urban economic areas and, at the same time, the progressive depletion of domestic sources of primary energy and a growing demand for energy, the conventional energy system has inevitably become ever more concentrated. To highlight a lack of storage possibilities as one of the principal drawbacks of renewable energies, however, is to take a superficial viewpoint. No modern energy supply system can exist without storage, because there is no simultaneity between primary energy generation or harvesting, and final energy use. The use of renewable energies in buildings and in urban planning, and the adaptation of buildings and orientation to the existing natural environment are critical elements in transforming energy supply at municipal level. At the same time urban planning in terms of distances between residential areas, work, recreation, and shopping areas is a key factor in determining transport behavior and hence energy consumption. The decentralized structures through to the Solar City are becoming increasingly attractive, offering diversity and flexibility. While conventional energy supply is a permanent and expensive; solar energy is becoming an autonomous value added factor for the city and its inhabitants. © 2008 Copyright © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Fuel cell distributed generation system for cooling
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Conference on Fuel Cell Science, Engineering, and Technology
Affiliations: Building and Energy Technologies Department, Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 24885, Safat, 13109, Kuwait; Department of Advanced Systems, Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 24885, Safat, 13109, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: ElSherbini, A.I., Building and Energy Technologies Department, Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 24885, Safat, 13109, Kuwait; Al-Qattan, A.M., Department of Advanced Systems, Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 24885, Safat, 13109, Kuwait
Abstract: Air conditioning (A/C) systems are the major consumers of power in hot climates. In a country like Kuwait, A/C accounts for 85% of power supplied to homes during peak hours and 55% of annual energy consumption by the residential sector. A fuel-cell-based cogeneration system is proposed to improve the efficiency of generating and utilizing power for cooling in residential buildings. Distributed electric power is generated by a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC). The electricity is used to operate high-efficiency water-cooled chillers in a district-cooling setup, which replaces packaged A/C units typically used for homes. The exhaust fuel and heat from the SOFC operate a gas turbine and an absorption chiller. A thermal energy storage tank is used for storing chilled water to reduce the total capacity of the system and, hence, capital investment. The integrated fuel-cell air-conditioning (FCAC) system improves the cooling-to-fuel efficiency, expressed as coefficient of performance, by 375%. The peak power requirement is reduced by 65% and the total fuel energy is reduced by 58%. An example system of 2 MW delivers 3750 RT (13.2 MW) of cooling to a district. Over a 9-month period, it saves 94 TJ of fuel energy and feeds 5.21 GWh of electricity to the grid as a surplus. Copyright © 2008 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Air-conditioning; Cogeneration; District cooling; Fuel cell; Solid oxide; Thermal storage
Index Keywords: A-thermal; Absorption chillers; Capital investment; Chilled water; Coefficient of Performance; Cogeneration; Cogeneration systems; Distributed generation system; District cooling; Electric power; Energy consumption; Fuel efficiency; Fuel energy; High efficiency; Hot climate; Peak power; Residential building; Residential sectors; Solid oxide; Thermal storage; Air conditioning; Cells; District heating; Electric generators; Energy utilization; Gas absorption; Heat storage; Investments; Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC); Water cooling systems; Fuel storage

Source title: 2008 1st International Conference on Infrastructure Systems and Services: Building Networks for a Brighter Future, INFRA 2008
Affiliations: Research and Technology Dept., National Iranian Gas Company, No.77-Southern Aban St.-Karimkhan Ave., Tehran-1598753113, Iran

Title: The importance of pumpedstorage for Bulgaria
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: NEK, HPP Rila Group Enterprise, 85, Simeonovsko Shousse, 1200 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Ivanov, P.Y., NEK, HPP Rila Group Enterprise, 85, Simeonovsko Shousse, 1200 Sofia, Bulgaria; Ruseva, N.N., NEK, HPP Rila Group Enterprise, 85, Simeonovsko Shousse, 1200 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The important role of pumped-storage for the Bulgarian grid system, and describes the pumped-storage stations currently in operation, with particular reference to Chaira, the largest of its type in Eastern Europe is discussed. The Chaira scheme was built in the Rila mountains, about 100 km southeast of the capital city, Sofia. The underground powerhouse cavern is about 350 m below the ground surface, and almost 1 km from the lower compensating basin. The operating capability of Chaira will increase with the future increase in capacity of the lower reservoir. The intention to increase the lower reservoir and the resulting advantages, such as a higher rate of utilization and operation of the power plant, are in full compliance with the strategic objectives of the Bulgarian energy sector, to ensure security of supply and sustainable economic development for the country.
Index Keywords: Bulgaria; Eastern Europe; Energy sector; Grid systems; Ground surfaces; Operating capability; Pumped storage station; Security of supply; Strategic objectives; Sustainable economic development; Underground powerhouse

Authors: Bissel C., Parkinson E., List B., Heimann A., Vullioud G.
Title: New perspectives for Pelton projects in a booming European wind energy market
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bissel, C., Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland; Parkinson, E., Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland; List, B., Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland; Heimann, A., Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland; Vullioud, G., Andritz VA TECH Hydro, Rue des deux Gares, 6, CH-1800 Vevey, Switzerland
Abstract: Following the expansion of wind energy use in Europe, pumped-storage and Pelton hydro plants are increasingly being constructed to compensate and help stabilize the energy distribution network. The mountainous region of the Alps plays a strategic role, and examples of new and rehabilitation projects are discussed here.
Index Keywords: Energy distribution networks; Hydro plants; Mountainous regions; Rehabilitation projects; Strategic role; Wind energy; Distributed parameter networks; Wind power

Title: The role of hydro and pumped storage in Bulgaria
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Velkov, L., NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria; Papazyan, M., NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The development and role of hydropower and pumped-storage in Bulgaria is discussed. The largest producer of hydroelectric power is the National Electricity Company of Bulgaria (NEK) which is 100 per cent State owned. NEK is the owner of 29 hydropower and pumped-storage plants, with a total installed capacity of 2563 MW. To increase the hydro output and reduce emissions pollutants and greenhouse gases associated with thermal plants, NEK is implementing plans for the construction of new hydropower schemes as well as the refurbishment of existing hydro and pumped-storage plants. Hydropower development is an integral part of the country's overall energy strategy. Hydropower is an established renewable technology which offers the environmental benefits associated with emerging renewable competitors at a cost-effective price, with dependable supply, and the added benefit of opportunities for continued expansion.
Index Keywords: Bulgaria; Electricity companies; Energy strategy; Environmental benefits; Hydro-power development; Installed capacity; Integral part; Pumped Storage; Pumped storage plants; Renewable technology; Thermal plants; Competition; Electric power generation; Energy management; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Hydroelectric power; Strategic planning; Hydroelectric power plants

Title: 2008 IEEE Region 10 Conference, TENCON 2008
Source title: IEEE Region 10 Annual International Conference, Proceedings/TENCON
Abstract: The proceedings contain 487 papers. The topics discussed include: low delay nearend speech detector for acoustic echo cancellation; adaptive power allocation for repetition based cooperative relay in Nakagami-m fading channel; a SAT approach for solving the nurse scheduling problem; a particle swarm optimization-based approach towards the solution of the dynamic channel assignment problem in mobile cellular networks; a direct method for transmission network cost allocation; an efficient maximum likelihood CFO estimation scheme for MIMO-OFDM systems; a data model in XML schema for an inference and diagnostic framework; a logarithmic CMOS digital pixel sensor; an improved deblocking filter for H.264; analysis and control of an autonomous hybrid wind-driven PM alternator and photovoltaic array without battery storage; system level energy aware fault tolerance approach for real time system; and dynamic voltage collapse prediction in a practical power system with support vector machine.

Title: Papers Presented at the 2007 E-MRS Fall Meeting, Symp. B: Chemical and Electrochemical Synthesis of Adv. Materials and Nanostructures on Solid Surfaces: Growth Mechanisms, Characterizations and Appl.
Source title: Physica Status Solidi (C) Current Topics in Solid State Physics
Abstract: The proceedings contain 29 papers. The topics discussed include: chemical solution deposited PbS thin films on Si(100); influence of treatment conditions on chalcopyrite films deposited at atmospheric pressure; new insights in the electrodeposition mechanism of CuInSe2 thin films for solar cell applications; synthesis and Seebeck coefficient of nanostructured phosphorus-alloyed bismuth telluride thick films; deposition of nano-crystalline lead chalcogenide thin films using a simple electrochemical technique; a cleaner approach towards deposition of CdS thin films by an electrochemical technique; development and characterization of electrochemically enlarged silicon electrodes for energy storage microcapacitors; porous silicon for field emission display applications; influence of surface pre-treatment in the room temperature fabrication of nanoporous alumina; and multicolour photochromic behaviour of silver nanoparticles in titanium dioxide matrix.

Authors: Kazemi A., Jamali S., Shateri H.
Title: Effects of SMES equipped SSSC on distance relay tripping characteristic
Source title: Transmission and Distribution Exposition Conference: 2008 IEEE PES Powering Toward the Future, PIMS 2008
Affiliations: Center of Excellence for Power Systems Automation and Operation, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Science and Technology (IUST), Narmak, Tehran 16844, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Kazemi, A., Center of Excellence for Power Systems Automation and Operation, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Science and Technology (IUST), Narmak, Tehran 16844, Iran; Jamali, S., Center of Excellence for Power Systems Automation and Operation, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Science and Technology (IUST), Narmak, Tehran 16844, Iran; Shateri, H., Center of Excellence for Power Systems Automation and Operation, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Science and Technology (IUST), Narmak, Tehran 16844, Iran
Abstract: This paper presents the measured impedance at the relaying point in the presence of one of the series connected Flexible Alternating Current Transmission System (FACTS) devices, i.e. Static Synchronous Series Compensator (SSSC) which is equipped with a Superconductor Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES). The presence of SMES equipped SSSC on a transmission line greatly influences the tripping characteristic of distance relays. Distance relay tripping characteristic itself depends on the power system structural conditions, pre-fault loading, and especially the ground fault resistance. In the presence of SMES equipped SSSC, its structural and controlling parameters as well as its connection point affect the tripping characteristic. Here, the measured impedance at the relaying point is calculated due to the mentioned parameters. ©2008 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Distance protection; FACTS devices; Fault resistance; SMES; SSSC; Tripping characteristic
Index Keywords: Connection points; Controlling parameters; Distance protection; Distance relay; Facts devices; Fault resistances; Flexible alternating current transmission systems; Ground faults; Magnetic energy storage; Measured impedance; Power systems; Static synchronous series compensator; Structural condition; Transmission line; Electric impedance; Electric power transmission; Electric relays; Magnetic storage; Superconducting magnets; Electric energy storage

Title: Synthesis and Processing of Organic and Polymeric Functional Materials for a Sustainable Energy Economy
Abstract: The proceedings contain 7 papers. The topics discussed include: self-assembled functional molecular materials for optoelectronic applications; highly transparent, tough and dimensionally stable polymer nanocomposite; on the photophysical and electrochemical studies of dye-sensitized solar cells; fiber-based bulk-heterojunction organic photovoltaic cells; photoactive donor-acceptor thin films as prospective materials for evaporated bulk heterojunctions of molecular semiconductors; subnanoporous polyacenic material for gas storage; and electrical, optical and morphological properties of P3HT/MWNT nanocomposite prepared by in-situ polymerization.

Title: System for processing, vizualizaition and data storage
Source title: 2008 International Conference Modern Technique and Technologies, MTT 2008
Affiliations: Brno University of Technology, Technicka 2848/8, Brno, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Procházka, Z., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 2848/8, Brno, Czech Republic; Machácek, J., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 2848/8, Brno, Czech Republic
Abstract: The present paper describes a system for measuring, collecting, analyzing, and displaying data. A 100W solar energy converter is used to monitor the effect of operating conditions on its loading characteristics. This photovoltaic (PV) cell and the associated measuring and data acquisition system have been installed in the solar laboratory (on a terraced roof) in the Department of Electrical Power Engineering, FEEC, BUT. Thanks to the system of collecting, archiving, and analyzing the data measured we can monitor, define, and subsequently interpret all positive and more significantly the negative external effects on the efficiency of the device.
Index Keywords: Data acquisition system; Data storage; Electrical power engineering; Loading characteristics; Operating condition; Soil conservation; Solar power generation; Solar energy

Title: Collaborating on CCS
Authors with affiliations: Griffin, J.
Abstract: With a world wanting more energy, provided in a stable and secure manner, and environmental protection high on the global agenda, it is important to promote, develop and deploy cleaner fossil fuel technologies. It is with this background, and as part of the EU-OPEC Energy Dialogue Work Programme that representatives from the OPEC Secretariat, OPEC Member Countries, the European Commission, other international organizations, as well as energy utilities and companies, gathered in Brussels for the Second EU-OPEC Roundtable on Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). A discussion covers the growing political and industry support for CCS technology at the international level; plans to integrate the technology into science and technology programs; CCS examples, e.g., demonstration project at In Salah in Algeria; challenges for the future wide-scale application of CCS technology; uncertainties over the link between greenhouse gas emissions and climate change; potential benefits and opportunities for CCS; cost issues; importance of broader international cooperation; legal and regulatory frameworks covering all the aspects of CCS; the need for more research, development, and deployment in all the various technologies; non-technical factors essential for CCS breakthrough; and the role of the EU-OPEC Energy Dialogue in promoting CCS.

Authors: Santarosa C., Ketzer J.M., Cunha P., Murce T.-S.
Title: Perspectives for the sustainable use of fossil fuels in Brazil with carbon sequestration in geological reservoirs
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Santarosa, C.; Ketzer, J.M.; Cunha, P.; Murce, T.-S.
Abstract: Brazil is in search of clean energy options in accordance to country's voluntary commitment to mitigate climate change. Carbon sequestration in geological reservoirs is one of the most promising technologies for the sustainable use of fossil fuels and, thus, many actions are being conducted to assure country readiness for this technology. These actions include capacity building, establishment of appropriated R&D infra-structure, e.g., CEPAC (Carbon Storage Research Center), and implementation of CO2 storage research, development, pilot, and demonstration projects in four onshore sedimentary basins and in the offshore Campos Basin. The projects aim to assure CO2 storage capacity and effectiveness in deep brine aquifers, coal seams, and petroleum fields to store CO2 for thousands of years. Pilot projects are expected to wherein ∼. 0.3 million ton/yr of CO2 will be injected by 2014. Demonstration projects are planned to store 3.9 million ton/yr of CO2 in the Campos Basin by 2008, 1.9 million ton/yr CO2 in the Potiguar Basin by 2011, etc. The amount of CO2 stored per year in demonstration projects by 2014 will be 90 million ton/yr CO2 to 18% of Petrobras' present-day emissions. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008).

Title: PETROBRAS - An energy company and the Brazilian biofuel program
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Torres, F.
Abstract: The global heating and the Earth climatic changes are occurring because of man's impact on the environment. Brazil's answer for this comes from the time of the First Petroleum Shock in September 1973 with the launching of the Alcohol National Program in November 1975. In December 2004, the National Program Production and the Use of Bio-Diesel (PNPB) was launched with possibility of utilization of any kind of oleaginous, privileging the family agriculture and encouraging the formation of cooperative and producers' consortium for bio-diesel production, using the technological route from ethanol. Petrobras, as an energy company, is participating actively on these national projects and investing in tankage collectors and storage, shipment and discharge marine terminals, distribution infrastructure and bio-diesel plant productions. The company intends to invest $1.5 billion in bio-fuel business acting globally in its commercialization and logistics, leading bio-diesel national production while and enlarging the participation in ethanol business. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008).

Title: Audience with His Majesty. The King of Spain
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Jenkins, C.
Abstract: Sustainability is at the heart of the EU's energy and climate policy. It is only by securing a sustainable energy future that men will also assure the future of the climate. If man continues on today's track, the world will be using one and a half times as much oil and gas by 2030 compared to today - which is hardly sustainable. Thus, the oil and gas industry must play a special role in a sustainable future. Some of the most exciting developments in renewable energy, solar power, or clean technologies, e.g., CO2 capture and storage and biofuels, are being led by oil and gas companies. The opportunities to strengthen the economy, to improve our quality of life, and create wealth and jobs, from clean and efficient energy, are huge. In 2008, the EU committed itself to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions, increasing the use of renewable energy, promoting investment in clean energy, and building up energy diplomacy. To realize this, the whole legal framework for energy in the EU needs to be reformed. These include agreements on new rules to complete an internal European energy market, the introduction of legislation to enforce the greenhouse gas and renewable targets, giving Europe the technology tools to deliver, and stimulating our partners to respond quickly, and decisively to the energy and climate challenge. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008).

Authors: Martin J., Moyano M., Mingst A., Schmall V.
Title: CDM after 2012 - Challenges and opportunities for Latin America and the Caribbean
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Martin, J.; Moyano, M.; Mingst, A.; Schmall, V.
Abstract: A discussion on the key policy issues to be considered in the architecture of the Kyoto Protocol after 2012 that would allow Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) to become an increasingly effective tool to mitigate climate change covers the CDM process; technology issues; and the short, medium, and long-term technological challenges and opportunities related to greenhouse gas management, including energy efficiency, gas flaring and venting reduction, and carbon capture and storage. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008-7/3/2008).

Authors: Sanchidrian I., Muina J.M.G., Sanchidrian C.
Title: LNG hub harbours: A proposal for regional energy offer/demand balance improvement
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Sanchidrian, I.; Muina, J.M.G.; Sanchidrian, C.
Abstract: Development of natural gas import hub harbors as LNG was proposed to contribute to regional balance. Development of such a concept would allow avoidance of local conflicts and its consequences setting a maritime transport bridge putting without disruptions natural gas in markets. Difficulties due to reduced experience regarding LNG terminals were also analyzed. The feasibility of a 6-10 LNG jetties supplying storage capacities up to 100 billion cu m was presented, showing its advantages and listing the entities that could be interested in such developments. The geographical areas of interest and possible strategic locations where to develop LNG hubs were also presented. The Spanish market and its necessities were studied. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008-7/3/2008).

Authors: Nagy S., Siemek J., Rychlicki S.
Title: Underground Gas Storages (UGS) as an element of the safety energy system
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Nagy, S.; Siemek, J.; Rychlicki, S.
Abstract: The position of UGS in eliminating or limiting the hazards related to gas delivery is presented. This is expected to be an element of the "chain" or gaseous system. UGS storages are an important element stabilizing the risk in energy economics, risk of regulation of gas market, and political risk. UGS plays a key role in covering the seasonal and peak gas demand. This would be a significant aspect of energy safety as far as imported gas delivery and public safety are concerned. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008-7/3/2008).

Title: Carbon capture and storage - Political, technological and economical constraints
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Affiliations: Det Norske Veritas, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Tørstad, E.H., Det Norske Veritas, Norway
Abstract: Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a large scale solution to climate change, consider to have significant potential on curbing CO2 emissions. Fossil fuels will continue to be our main energy source for decades to come, and CCS can contribute with as much as 55% of the emissions reductions needed to stabilize climate change. A discussion on CSS covers its lack of maturity in terms of frame conditions; need for integrated risk management throughout the life cycle of a CCS project; addressing the legal and economical responsibilities and liabilities, and how these are distributed between the involved parties; demonstration projects as a tool for development of technology at competitive cost and to acceptable HSE standards; uncertainties and risks involved in CCS, e.g., societal, commercial, and technical issues; and shortening the time span from policy making to industry implementation. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008).

Title: Central and Eastern Europes answer to energy dependency
Source title: Energy Institute - 19th World Petroleum Congress 2008: A World in Transition: Delivering Energy for Sustainable Growth
Authors with affiliations: Lakatos, B.
Abstract: Nabucco and SEP are the most well-known pipeline projects aiming at diversifying the resource portfolio of the region by transit deliveries of sources, enabling the affected countries to establish an effective market. Several projects were launched to deliver new sources in the form of LNG. Local pipeline interconnections need to be paid attention, since they increase flexibility and security for a smaller region. Handling increased gas quantities is unimaginable without gas storages with appropriate peak and mobile capacities, because of strategic reasons and for sustaining the gas balance of surrounding countries and flat delivery of gas sources. MOL takes up an active role in pipeline projects. MOL has 20% share in Nabucco and 50% share in SEP, is working on the establishment of several local pipeline interconnections and capacity expansion. MOL has also potential to develop over 10 billion cu m UGS capacities in depleted or currently working gas fields in Hungary. Western Europe relies heavily on LNG gas, which could also merge into CEE at the planned and under construction terminals in the Adriatic region. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 19th World Petroleum Congress (Madrid, Spain 6/29/2008-7/3/2008).

Title: Mobile Energy
Abstract: The proceedings contain 16 papers. The topics discussed include: structure and electrochemistry of carbon-bromine nanocomposite electrodes for electrochemical energy storage; reduction of bis(oxalato)borate on a high surface area carbon electrode; development of ultrahigh surface area porous electrodes using simultaneous and sequential meso- and micro-structuring methods; recent progress with ethyleneoxy phosphazenes as lithium battery electrolytes; formation of GaN nanocrystal on Si and its photoelectrochemical application; structure and electrochemistry of novel silver metal oxyfluoride perovskite: cathode materials for high volumetric energy storage; and computer simulation of structural stability by hydrogenation in hydrogen storage materials.

Authors: Nakas-Icindic E., Valjevac A., Zaciragic A.
Title: Adipokines and acute coronary syndrome
Affiliations: Institute of Physiology and Biochemistry, Medical Faculty, University of Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Authors with affiliations: Nakas-Icindic, E., Institute of Physiology and Biochemistry, Medical Faculty, University of Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina; Valjevac, A., Institute of Physiology and Biochemistry, Medical Faculty, University of Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina; Zaciragic, A., Institute of Physiology and Biochemistry, Medical Faculty, University of Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
Abstract: Adipose tissue has traditionally been considered as a tissue devoted mainly to energy storage. Now it is recognized as a multifunctional organ involved in the production of hormones, growth factors and cytokines named adipokines. In obese subject the production of adipokines is impaired. In obesity high level of leptin, resistin, and low level of adiponectin have been observed and implicated in insulin resistance, atherosclerosis and metabolic syndrome. In patients with established coronary atherosclerosis increased body weight is an independent predictor of an acute coronary syndrome. The exact mechanism of obesity induced coronary heart disease is not fully elucidated. Current research is aimed to determine links between adipokines and coronary heart disease. Leptin, adiponectin and resistin are adipokines that are implicated in coronary endothelial dysfunction, trombogenesis and inflammation. These processes are known to precipitate atherosclerotic plaque rupture and acute coronary syndrome. Recent studies demonstrated that high plasma leptin and low adiponectin levels as observed in obese subjects impair coronary acetylcholine-mediated vasodilatation in vitro and in vivo. Resistin also impair coronary vasodilatation but via brady-kinin pathway. Leptin and resistin show proinflammatory effects upregulating cytokine production in macrophages and might lead to destabilization of coronary atherosclerotic plaque. Leptin has been observed to stimulate angiogenesis, platelet aggregation, and atherothrombosis in obese human. In obese subject the production of adiponectin, which has protective effects on coronary blood vessels is suppressed. This paper summarizes the role of three adipokines: leptin, resistin and adiponectin in acute coronary syndrome and implicates theirs possible appliance in clinical practice.
Author Keywords: Acute coronary syndrome; Adipokines; Adiponectin; Leptin; Resistin

Title: Nanoscale materials for hydrogen and fuel cell systems
Source title: NATO Science for Peace and Security Series B: Physics and Biophysics
Affiliations: UNIDO - International Centre for Hydrogen Energy Technologies, Sabri Ulker Sk. 38/4, Istanbul 34015, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Yazici, M.S., UNIDO - International Centre for Hydrogen Energy Technologies, Sabri Ulker Sk. 38/4, Istanbul 34015, Turkey
Abstract: The emphasis put on future "Hydrogen Economy" requires technologies further develop around "production", "storage" and "utilization" for durability and cost reduction. Extended life time, performance and higher efficiencies are reported for fuel cell technologies utilizing nanostructures (tubes, fibers, and particles). New nanocomposites, better catalyst utilizations, nanoscale engineering of interfaces are some of the examples of success in energy applications. This wide spread popularity will result advancement against issues preventing commercialization of hydrogen technologies and fuel cell systems. © 2008 Springer Netherlands.
Author Keywords: Energy; Fuel cells; Hydrogen; Nanomaterials

Title: A power quality monitoring system for real-time detection of power fluctuations
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Rajamangala University of Technology Lanna, Chiang Mai 50300, Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Yingkayun, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Rajamangala University of Technology Lanna, Chiang Mai 50300, Thailand; Premrudeepreechacharn, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand
Abstract: Due to the increasingly of the industry, the requirement of the power quality is more important. In the event of a short period of the power failure, it will lead to make an unpredictable of loss. In order to decrease the power failure occurrence, the power quality monitoring system development is required. This paper presents the methodology for monitoring the power quality (PQ) by implement the monitoring system that able to detect the power fluctuation in real-time. The monitoring system acquired the power signals by using power measurement IC which perform calculation of power quality indexes which interfaced by using ARM7 microcontroller. The monitoring system uses the energy measurement integrated circuit (IC) ADE7758 with power quality monitoring features from Analog Devices Incorporation. The monitoring system detects for sag and swells voltage and stored to external storage device ©2008 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Integrated circuit (IC); Power fluctuation; Power quality (pq)
Index Keywords: ADE7758; Analog devices; Energy measurements; Monitoring system; Power failure; Power fluctuation; Power fluctuations; Power measurement; Power quality monitoring; Power quality monitoring system; Power signals; Real-time detection; Short periods; Storage devices; Electric energy storage; Electric power measurement; Integrated circuits; Monitoring

Title: Proceedings of the 46th Annual Southeast Regional Conference on XX, ACM-SE 46
Source title: Proceedings of the 46th Annual Southeast Regional Conference on XX, ACM-SE 46
Abstract: The proceedings contain 109 papers. The topics discussed include: high precision automatic scheduling of periodic task sets for microcontrollers; energy efficient and reliable storage disks; customized file systems: an investigator's approach; biometrics education with hands-on labs; FunFonts: introducing 4th and 5th graders to programming using squeak; a review of using design patterns in CS1; mining frequent sequential patterns with first-occurrence forests; a bioinformatics-inspired adaptation to Ukkonens edit distance calculating algorithm; training approaches in neural enhancement for multiobjective optimization; generating better text summaries for a patient simulation program; optimal artificial neural network topology for foreign exchange forecasting; evaluating service-based software applications; comparison of microarray image analysis software; SubCOID: an attempt to explore cluster-outlier iterative detection approach to multi-dimensional data analysis in subspace; and effects of multiple words on ambiguity in information retrieval.

Title: Integration of safeguards into the design and operation of a 40,000 MTU spent nuclear fuel storage facility
Source title: 8th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface 2008
Affiliations: Private Fuel Storage LLC
Authors with affiliations: Parkyn, J., Private Fuel Storage LLC
Abstract: The Safeguards concerns for spent nuclear fuel since 9/11/01 have drawn great public attention. The issue of separation from populations, detection of strangers and intruders and the ability to mobilize the local population as an extended security force are key concerns. The project is able to gain isolation, which decreases masking of intruders and speeds response of security forces. The restricted airspace greatly reduces the chance of intentional intrusion using aircraft. Thorough analysis of the facility and dry cask designs provides an additional margin against cask failure and consequences under conditions of intentional attack by those whose desire is to create an incident harmful to the nation. The recovery from such events is enhanced by the criteria used to separate the facility from surface water and groundwater, which could provide dispersion pathways enhancing the damage, which would reinforce the intentions of those causing the event. The paper will cover the design criteria for site selection as well as the concerns for intentional intrusion.
Index Keywords: Design and operations; Design criterion; Intentional Attacks; Local populations; Security forces; Spent nuclear fuels; Storage facilities; Aircraft; Aircraft accidents; Enhanced recovery; Groundwater; Hydrogeology; Network security; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Quality assurance; Radioactive wastes; Site selection; Fuel storage

Title: Nanostructured Materials for Energy Storage and Conversion - Proceedings of the International Symposium
Abstract: The proceedings contain 29 papers. The topics discussed include: nanostructured materials for batteries and fuel cells; nanostructured PtRu films for combinatorial studies of fuel cell catalysis; fuel cell carbon materials modified by in-situ generated diazonium salt; investigation of lithium intercalation in nanostructured iron and manganese oxides; electron spin resonance studies of Li-substituted manganese spinel structures synthesized by wet chemistry; structural and magnetic properties of glassy phosphates with nasicon-like framework; FUIR features of lithium iron phosphates used as positive electrodes in rechargeable lithium batteries; long-range and local structural properties of phospho-olivine compounds synthesized by wet chemistry; and synthesis and characterization of mesoporous, nanorods, nanowires metal oxides.

Authors: Eftekhari A., Kazemzad M., Moztarzadeh F.
Title: Flower-like microparticles of LiMn2O4 nanofibers
Affiliations: Laboratory of Electrochemistry, Materials and Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 14155-4777, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Eftekhari, A., Laboratory of Electrochemistry, Materials and Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 14155-4777, Tehran, Iran; Kazemzad, M., Laboratory of Electrochemistry, Materials and Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 14155-4777, Tehran, Iran; Moztarzadeh, F., Laboratory of Electrochemistry, Materials and Energy Research Center, P.O. Box 14155-4777, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: A new bunching of nanomaterials is reported, as nanofibers (ca. 10-50 nm in diameter) form huge skeins of ca. 20-50 μm. LiMn2O4, which is a promising candidate for lithium batteries and needs improvement of solid-state diffusion, was synthesized with this nanostructure. The process was simply a hydrothermal synthesis of LiMn2O4 while vanadium as a dopant is incorporated into the spinel lattice. This work reports a novel bunching phenomenon in the realms of solid-state physics and nanotechnology.
Index Keywords: Flower-like; Micro-particles; Nano-materials; Solid-state diffusion; Spinel lattices; Diffusion in solids; Energy storage; Flywheels; Lithium alloys; Nanofibers; Nanostructured materials; Nanostructures; Vanadium; Hydrothermal synthesis

Title: Nanoporous carbide-derived carbon as electrode material for electrical double layer capacitors
Affiliations: Institute of Physical Chemistry, University of Tartu, 2 Jakobi Str., 51014, Tartu, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Jänes, A., Institute of Physical Chemistry, University of Tartu, 2 Jakobi Str., 51014, Tartu, Estonia; Lust, E., Institute of Physical Chemistry, University of Tartu, 2 Jakobi Str., 51014, Tartu, Estonia
Abstract: Electrochemical characteristics for the 1 M nonaqueous electrolyte | nanoporous carbide-derived carbon (prepared from TiC, α-SiC, MO 2C, Al4C3 and B4C) interface have been established by cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. The gas adsorption measurements have been used for the obtaining the specific surface area, pore size distribution, nanopore volume and other characteristics, dependent on the precursor carbide used (nanopores are pores in the range of 2 nm and below - i.e. micropores according to IUPAC classification).
Index Keywords: Carbide derived carbon; Electrical double layer capacitor; Electrochemical characteristics; Electrode material; Micropores; Nano-porous; Non-aqueous electrolytes; Cyclic voltammetry; Electric properties; Electrochemical corrosion; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrolytic capacitors; Energy storage; Flywheels; Gas adsorption; Nanopores; Nanostructured materials; Pore size; Silicon carbide; Titanium carbide; Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy

Authors: Turkovic A., Pavlović M., Ivanda M., Gaberšček M., Orel Z.C.
Title: Influence of intercalated lithium on structural and electrical properties of V2O5, mixed V/Ce oxide and Fe2O3
Affiliations: Institute Ruder Bošković, P.O. Box 1016, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; National Institute of Chemistry, SI-1001, Ljubljana, Hajdrihova 19, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Turkovic, A., Institute Ruder Bošković, P.O. Box 1016, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; Pavlović, M., Institute Ruder Bošković, P.O. Box 1016, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; Ivanda, M., Institute Ruder Bošković, P.O. Box 1016, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; Gaberšček, M., National Institute of Chemistry, SI-1001, Ljubljana, Hajdrihova 19, Slovenia; Orel, Z.C., National Institute of Chemistry, SI-1001, Ljubljana, Hajdrihova 19, Slovenia
Abstract: We have investigated thin-films containing nanosized grains of V 2O5, new V/Ce oxides, Fe2O3 and V2O5, V/Ce and Fe2O3 with Li by the thermally stimulated currents (TSC), impedance spectroscopy (IS), Raman spectroscopy and grazing-incidence small-angle X-ray scattering (GISAXS) at the ELETTRA synchrotron (Italy, Trieste). Combining different experimental methods, the dependence of structural and electrical properties upon percentage of Li added into the matrix of these metal-oxide films was found. These changes are explained by the structural changes of grains (and grain boundaries) and with the impact of Li+ ions in the charge transfers. The average grain radius <R>, obtained by GISAXS increased in V/Ce oxide at 38 at. % of V upon the intercalation of Li+ ions. This particular morphology is quite suitable for application in electrochromic devices, in an advanced electrochemical cell concept and efficient new solar cells.
Index Keywords: Experimental methods; Gi-SAXS; Grain radius; Grazing incidence small-angle X-ray scattering; Impedance spectroscopy; matrix; Metal oxide film; Nanosized grains; Structural and electrical properties; Structural change; Thermally stimulated current; Trieste; Charge transfer; Electric batteries; Electric properties; Electrolytic cells; Energy storage; Flywheels; Grain boundaries; Ion exchange; Lithium; Metal analysis; Nanostructured materials; Raman spectroscopy; X ray scattering; Oxide films

Title: Developing an effective climate change strategy
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Abstract: A discussion on the options that the corporate leaders have at their disposal for developing an effective climate change strategy covers the impact of federal greenhouse gas regulation on climate change strategy; derivation of business value from energy efficiency and renewable energy projects; benefits of carbon trading; investment in carbon capture and storage projects; and carbon credits from methane management. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 101st AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Portland, OR 6/24-27/2008).

Title: Impact of nuclear renaissance on waste management programs: A South Africa perspective
Source title: American Nuclear Society - 12th International High-Level Radioactive Waste Management Conference 2008
Affiliations: Waste and Nuclear Liability Management Group, PBMR (Pty) Ltd, Fuel Division, P. O. Box 9396, Centurion, 0046, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Makgae, M.E., Waste and Nuclear Liability Management Group, PBMR (Pty) Ltd, Fuel Division, P. O. Box 9396, Centurion, 0046, South Africa; Hlatshwayo, Z.N., Waste and Nuclear Liability Management Group, PBMR (Pty) Ltd, Fuel Division, P. O. Box 9396, Centurion, 0046, South Africa
Abstract: Nuclear renaissance in South Africa has been prompted by various factors. As a developing country, South Africa has met challenges associated with economic growth. Such challenges include increased energy demand, exploring alternative sources of energy, trying to reduce carbon emissions and its associated environmental impacts. South Africa is embarking on the expansion of the Nuclear Energy Program. It has developed legislation for this expansion to take place in an organized, transparent and responsible manner. Some of the strategic actions that the government is planning are uranium mining and milling, conversion, enrichment, fuel fabrication and power generation. All these will impact highly on the generation of radioactive waste and will therefore require rigorous waste management planning. To try and address the associated impacts South Africa is in the process of establishing the National Radioactive Waste Management Agency. The guiding principles for the establishment of this Agency include: 4. Transparency and openness to the public A. Involvement of stakeholders 4 Polluter pays principle A Sound decision making based on scientific information, risk analysis and optimisation of resources The Agency will oversee the implementation of the National Radioactive Waste Management Strategy. The Strategy covers the total life cycle of waste management from generation through institutional control to disposal. This national commitment provides future generations with freedom of choice and builds confidence that all radioactive waste disposal options have been thoroughly investigated. The following hierarchy of the waste management options shall be followed wherever practicable: 4 Radioactive waste avoidance and minimization 4. Reuse, reprocessing and recycling 4 Storage 4 Conditioning and disposal This paper explores what the impacts of nuclear renaissance will be on waste management programs in South Africa.
Index Keywords: Alternative sources of energy; Carbon emissions; Economic growths; Energy demands; Fuel fabrications; Future generations; Government IS; Guiding principles; Institutional control; Nuclear renaissance; Optimisations; Polluter-pays principle; Scientific information; Sound decision; South Africa; Total life; Uranium mining; Waste management planning; Waste management program; Computer software reusability; Developing countries; Energy management; Environmental impact; Industrial waste treatment; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Planning; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Risk analysis; Risk assessment; Safety factor; Transuranium elements; Uranium; Waste disposal; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Sobotovich E., Zlobenko B., Spasova L., Pavlenko A., Alexeeva Z.
Title: Ukrainian general provisions on safe disposal of radioactive waste in geological repositories
Source title: American Nuclear Society - 12th International High-Level Radioactive Waste Management Conference 2008
Affiliations: Institute of Environmental Geochemistry, Palladin ave., 34 a, Kiyv, Ukraine, 03142, Ukraine; State Enterprise, V. Stus st., 35-37, Kiyv, Ukraine, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Sobotovich, E., Institute of Environmental Geochemistry, Palladin ave., 34 a, Kiyv, Ukraine, 03142, Ukraine; Zlobenko, B., Institute of Environmental Geochemistry, Palladin ave., 34 a, Kiyv, Ukraine, 03142, Ukraine; Spasova, L., Institute of Environmental Geochemistry, Palladin ave., 34 a, Kiyv, Ukraine, 03142, Ukraine; Pavlenko, A., State Enterprise, V. Stus st., 35-37, Kiyv, Ukraine, Ukraine; Alexeeva, Z., State Enterprise, V. Stus st., 35-37, Kiyv, Ukraine, Ukraine
Abstract: As a result of the previous and ongoing nuclear power programmes, Ukraine accumulates substantial amounts of spent fuel and radioactive wastes. While these wastes will be stored in temporary facilities, it is envisaged that final disposal will take place in a deep geological repository. Radiation safety of long-lived high and medium level waste disposal is of central importance for Ukraine today since considerable amount of waste from the Chernobyl accident, "Shelter" object's radioactive waste and fuel-containing materials and power industry wastes have been accumulated at the storage sites. Disposal of such wastes in geological repositories in deep stable formations is recognized to be the most foolproof method excluding radioactive waste penetration into environment over thousands of years. To solve the problem of radioactive waste disposal in geological repositories, the first-priority tasks are the following: implementation of regulatory and legal framework for managing radioactive waste to be disposed of in deep geological formations, and develop a regulation to govern the general provisions on safe disposal of radioactive waste in geological repositories. National legal regulation system of nuclear and radiation safety for radioactive waste geological disposal is to be developed in Ukraine. The first document of this kind is General Regulations for Safe Radioactive Waste Disposal in Geological Repositories" entered at Ministry of Justice of Ukraine on 11/06/2007. The provisions of this document are based on principles and requirements of IAEA and ICRP, consider national and foreign experience gained at radioactive waste management objects. This document consists of four clauses. The first one "General Provisions "presents the aim, the field of application and general characteristics of the object. Principles of Safe Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Geological Repositories" describes the manner of radioactive waste management: environmental and population health protection now and in future not imposing excessive load on the future generations, prevention of the repository's impact outside the national territory and holding on principles of radiological protection of population. Requirements for Safe Radioactive Waste Disposal in Geological Repositories" consists of several sub-clauses containing general requirements to accident prevention at various stages of the repository's flfe cycle - site selection, designing, construction, operation and shutdown. In the clauses devoted to implementation of the aims, the rpiain attention is paid to safety evaluation ensuring the protection level for the personnel, population and environment provided by regulations, rules and standards for nuclear and radiation safety as well as necessary technical decision support etc. The clause "Quality Assurance" comprises a complex of stage-by-stage measures directed at control of meeting the safety conditions in site selection, designing, construction, operation and shutdown. Implementation of the document will allow improving of the present radioactive waste management methods and creation on this basis of independent documents on site-seleclion, designing and construction of the geological repository. That will make possible the practical actions in the problem of radioactive waste disposal in Ukraine.
Index Keywords: Chernobyl accident; Deep geological repository; Future generations; Geological disposals; Geological formation; Legal frameworks; Legal regulation; Nuclear power; Population health; Power industry; Priority tasks; Protection level; Radiation safety; Radiological protection; Safe disposals; Safety condition; Safety evaluations; Storage sites; Technical decision; Temporary facilities; Ukraine; Decision support systems; Energy conversion; Fuel storage; Geological repositories; Industrial waste treatment; Laws and legislation; Nuclear reactor accidents; Personnel selection; Plant shutdowns; Quality assurance; Radiation protection; Radiation shielding; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Site selection; Spent fuels; Stages; Total quality management; Waste disposal; Radioactive waste disposal

Title: Materials Research for Electrical Energy Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 9 papers. The topics discussed include: modeling particle size effects on phase stability and transition pathways in nanosized olivine cathode particles; thermoelectric properties of YbBiPt and YBiPt thin films; surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry studies of Ni-rich oxide nanowires as electrode material; pseudo-capacitor structure for direct nuclear energy conversion; experimental research on thermal energy storage of a new type of PCM heat exchanger; materials research for high energy density electrochemical capacitor; microporous carbon-halide nanocomposites electrodes for symmetric and asymmetric capacitor; review on development and investigations of phase change materials in thermal energy storage; and high conducting heterovalent substituted NASICON-like phases in ScPo 44-Na3PO4 quasibinary system.

Title: Scaling and stabilization due to the large ion Larmor radius (LLR) effects in plasma focus devices
Authors with affiliations: Pavez, C.; Soto, L.
Abstract: Empirical and theoretical relationships based on the model developed by S Lee and the scaling laws observed in plasma focus (PF) devices are considered for determining the optimal regime of operation, where the large Larmor radius (LLR) effects would play a significant role in the reduction of the growth rate of the m=0 mode in the pinch column. That is, a range of values for the current of the pinch, the energy of the generator, the anode radius and an average filling pressure. On the other hand, it is found that the PFs in which enhanced stability could be observed, owing to LLR effects, are restricted to devices operating in a range of storage energy that goes from a few hundreds of joules to few kilojoules. Experimental results obtained in a PF with storage energy of the order of 400 J are discussed. © 2008 The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.
Index Keywords: Enhanced stability; Filling pressures; Larmor radii; Plasma focus devices; Regime of operation; Storage energy; Lunar surface analysis; Plasma devices; Plasmas

Title: 2008 IEEE Energy 2030 Conference, ENERGY 2008
Abstract: The proceedings contain 82 papers. The topics discussed include: an indoor localization algorithm for lighting control using RFID; AC grid with embedded VSC-HVDC for secure and efficient power delivery; a survey of systems to integrate distributed energy resources and energy storage on the utility grid; fault current limiter placement strategies and evaluation in two example systems; energy & national security: an exploration of threats, solutions, and alternative futures; power system level impacts of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles using simulation data; from power line to pipeline - creating an efficient and sustainable market structure; testing of power electronic modules for distributed systems at the national center for reliable electric power transmission; and intelligent scheduling of hybrid and electric vehicle storage capacity in a parking lot for profit maximization in grid power transactions.

Title: Biochemical changes in lipids of lyophilized meat foods during storage
Affiliations: Institute of Cryobiology and Food Technologies, BG - 1407 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Georgieva, L., Institute of Cryobiology and Food Technologies, BG - 1407 Sofia, Bulgaria; Tsvetkov, T., Institute of Cryobiology and Food Technologies, BG - 1407 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: GEORGIEVA, L. and Tsv. TSVETKOV, 2008. Biochemical changes in lipids of lyophilized meat foods during storage. Bulg. J. Agric. Sci., 14: 357-360 The nutritional value of lipids depends not only on their energy equivalent but on the metabolism, structure, composition and changes occurring during technological processing of the product as well. The characteristic of unsaturated lipids determines their ability to enter into reactions with molecular oxygen. As a result, the accumulation of oxidized products causes damage to health. The character and quantity of the oxidized products are closely related to temperature and thermal effect, presence of water, salts, hemoglobin and myoglobin, amino acids, free fatty acids etc.
Author Keywords: Freeze - drying; Lipids; Meat foods; Oxidative processes

Authors: Negut G., Ionita G., Niculae O., Durdun I., Diaconu S.
Title: Radioactive waste management in Romania
Source title: International Conference on Advances in Nuclear Power Plants, ICAPP 2008
Affiliations: National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Negut, G., National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania; Ionita, G., National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania; Niculae, O., National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania; Durdun, I., National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania; Diaconu, S., National Agency for Radioactive Waste (ANDRAD), 1, Campului Str., 115400 Mioveni, Romania
Abstract: In Romania, the radioactive waste results from nuclear industty and from the applications of the nuclear energy in research, medicine, industry and agriculture. The main producers of radioactive waste are: Nuclear Power Plant - Unit 1 & 2 of Cernavoda Nuclear Power Plant; Nuclear Research Reactors - VVRS IFJN-HH and TRIGA SCN-Pitesti; The Factoty which produces nuclear fuel Nuclear Fuel Plant (FCN-Pitesti Mining facilities and uranium processing facilities - The Uranium National Company; Hospitals which use applications of the radioisotopes in medical field (radiology, oncology); Classical industry, as a consequence of the industrial applications (the use of radioactive, sources in weld testing, leak detection, wall thickness measurement, etc.). According to the Romanian legislation in force, the licensees who produce radioactive waste are responsible for the safe management of the radioactive waste up to the moment of disposal. National Agency Radioactive Waste ANDRAD was created on the basis of the Governmental Ordinance No.11/2003 on the 28th of August 2004. ANDRAD is responsible for the disposal of the radioactive waste and the spent nuclear fuel. In order to achieve this objective ANDRAD has to develop a lot of activities, defined in the Governmental Ordinance No. 11/2003 modified and completed in 2007. The paper deals with the most important aspects of radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel management, the ANDRAD responsibilities in this area. The main nuclear waste management facilities the National Nuclear Waste Repository (DNDR) Baita, the nuclear waste storage, treatment and conditioning plants are presented. The Low and Intermediate Level Waste (LILW) storage facility (DIDR) and spent fuel storage (DICA) are presented, also. ANDRAD is responsible for the future LILW DFDSMA which is to be built at Saligny, near Cernavoda NPP site and future High Level Waste (HLW) and spent fuel repository (DFCA). This year was approved by the Governmental Ordinance the charge for waste produced nuclear power stations that will be used for nuclear waste management. There are finalized safety studies for LILW final repository and is in the process licensing procedures.
Index Keywords: High level waste; Intermediate level wastes; Licensing procedures; Medical fields; Nuclear power station; Nuclear research reactor; Nuclear waste management; Nuclear waste repositories; Nuclear waste storage; Romania; Safety studies; Spent fuel repositories; Spent nuclear fuel management; Spent nuclear fuels; Storage facilities; Uranium processing; Wall thickness; Energy conversion; Fuel storage; Fuels; Geological repositories; Industrial applications; Industrial research; Industrial waste treatment; Nuclear energy; Nuclear industry; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Radioisotopes; Spent fuels; Thickness measurement; Transuranium elements; Uranium; Waste disposal; Radioactive waste disposal
