Title: Statistics: Imports of crude and products: Refinery report - May 9, 2008: OGJ production report: US natural gas storage: World oil balance: OECD total net oil imports: OECD total gross imports from OPEC: US petroleum imports from source country: Oil stocks in oecd countries
Abstract: Data on API imports of crude (Canadian and other foreign) and products, i.e., total motor gasoline, motor gasoline blending component, distillate, residual, jet fuel (naphtha and kerosene), LPG, unfinished oils, and other products, for Districts 1-5 as of 5/2/2008 and 5/9/2008, as well as for the US as of 5/11/2007, 5/2/2008, and 5/9/2008 are tabulated. Data on refinery operations, e.g., total refinery input, crude runs, input to crude stills, operable capacity, and percent operated, as well as refinery output of total motor gasoline, jet fuels (naphtha and kerosene), and fuel oils (distillate and residual) for the Districts 1-5 as of 5/9/2008 are also presented. A production report on crude oil and lease condensate as of 5/18/2007 and 5/16/2008 is tabulated. EIA tabulated data on US natural gas storage as of 5/9/2007, 5/2/2008, and 5/9/2008. Based on the DOE International Petroleum Monthly Report, OECD net oil imports and OECD imports from OPEC as of November 2007, December 207, and January 2008 are also presented. DOE Monthly Energy Review reports the US petroleum imports from source country, e.g., Algeria, Kuwait, Angola, Canada, and other OPEC and non-OPEC members, from December 2007 to January 2008.

Authors: Bhuyan S., Hu J., Sun C.Q.
Title: Wireless drive of a piezoelectric plate by capacitorlike structure in electric resonance with an inductor
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Bhuyan, S., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Hu, J., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Sun, C.Q., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: A new technique of wirelessly transmitting electric energy to piezoelectric components is explored. In the design, an ac electric field is focused to a piezoelectric plate placed between plate-shaped live and needle ground electrodes which form a capacitorlike electric field generator in series with an inductor. The transmission of electric energy is enhanced when the capacitorlike electric field generator and inductor are in electric resonance. Experimentally it has been found that the real output power delivered to the piezoelectric plate depends on the electrode pattern, vibration mode, and electrical load of the piezoelectric component and the electric field focused by the needle ground and live electrodes. When the operating frequency is close to mechanical resonance frequency of the piezoelectric plate operating in the thickness vibration mode, a maximum output power of 0.264 W and energy conversion efficiency of 1.02% have been achieved with an input voltage 150 Vrms and 10 mm electrode separation. © 2008 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Conversion efficiency; Electric potential; Electrodes; Energy storage; Resonance; Capacitorlike electric field generators; Electric resonance; Piezoelectric components; Piezoelectric plates; Piezoelectric devices

Authors: Xavier D.D., León N.B.O., Abraham H. D.-P.
Title: Design and construction of a high voltage pulsed source for electric excitation of the gas laser
Affiliations: Popular University of the Cesar, Valledupar, Colombia; Spectroscopy and Laser Group, Popular University of the Cesar, Valledupar, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Xavier, D.D., Popular University of the Cesar, Valledupar, Colombia; León, N.B.O., Spectroscopy and Laser Group, Popular University of the Cesar, Valledupar, Colombia; Abraham H., D.-P., Spectroscopy and Laser Group, Popular University of the Cesar, Valledupar, Colombia
Abstract: In this paper, the design, construction and implementation of High Voltage Pulsed Source for Electrical Excitation of the Gas Lasers, as a first phase of the research project "Design and Construction of an economically and reliable Laser System constituted by a molecular pulsed laser and a single optical head for dyes" is presented. We proposed and considered the design and the construction of a source of pulsed high voltage that adjusts to the requirements of the pumping system that requires a low pressure nitrogen laser. The design and construction of the source high voltage prototype is presented like part of the electrical pumping system for a Pulsed Nitrogen Laser. The electrical pumping System is conformed by three subsystems: the high pulsed regulated voltage Source, the storage and unloading system of electrical energy of active medium, and the frequency control system of discharge repetition (spark gap) constituted by a circuit RLC and the electrodes of the laser discharge tube. In the present work the aspects related to the pulsed high regulated voltage Source is presented, Our Source of high pulsed voltage is constituted by four fundamental stages: the Stage of Conversion AC-DC (voltage reducer), the Stage of Commutation by means of a Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor (IGBT), the stage of Generation of signal modulated by the pulses width "PWM"(with base to Circuit TL 494) and the Stage of Elevation of Voltage (using a FlyBack Transformer). © 2008 American Institute of Physics.
Author Keywords: High voltage commutation; Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor (IGBT); Pulse Width Modulation (PWM)

Title: New developments on covers and coatings
Abstract: Voith is focusing on the development of the roll cover or coatings in the paper machine in order to meet the growing demands of the paper making process and for for fulfilling the expectations of the paper makers. The major objectives of these developments includes cost saving, reduction of energy consumption, improvement of paper quality, and improvement of paper machine efficiency. The various factors that needs to be taken into account are temperature, chemicals used, speed, production paper quality, nip impression measurements, and water balance calculations. The new polyurethane composition of the Solar series is the latest development in the roll covers consisting of engineered cover material that allows greater water storage capacity of the suction press roll and a deeper grooving of the press roll. TerraGloss is the new thermal coating for the hard calender rolls that increases the operational time and reduces the line load.
Index Keywords: Electric power utilization; Paper products; Polyurethanes; Nip impression measurements; Water balance; Papermaking machinery; Paper Machines; Paper Products; Paper Quality; Polyurethanes

Authors: Sosman L.P., Tavares Jr. A.D., Da Fonseca R.J.M., Papa A.R.R.
Title: Temperature and impurity concentration effects on Mg(1-x)Co xGa2O4 photoluminescence
Affiliations: IFADT, Univ. do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua S. Francisco Xavier 524, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20559-900, Brazil; Observatório Nacional, Rua Gal. José Cristino 77, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20921-400, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Sosman, L.P., IFADT, Univ. do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua S. Francisco Xavier 524, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20559-900, Brazil; Tavares Jr., A.D., IFADT, Univ. do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua S. Francisco Xavier 524, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20559-900, Brazil; Da Fonseca, R.J.M., IFADT, Univ. do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua S. Francisco Xavier 524, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20559-900, Brazil; Papa, A.R.R., IFADT, Univ. do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Rua S. Francisco Xavier 524, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20559-900, Brazil, Observatório Nacional, Rua Gal. José Cristino 77, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, 20921-400, Brazil
Abstract: Ceramic materials doped with magnetic ions that present emission in the visible and near-infrared spectral regions are very attractive due to their inherent tunability. Possible applications include their utilization as optoelectronic and display devices, as spintronic material, in signal transmission and information storage, in the fabrication of special papers, as dosimetric materials and room, temperature solid state lasers. Materials doped with tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ present wide bands originated from electronic transitions in the ionic unfilled 3d electronic shell. The Co2+ 3d electrons are outside of the ion core and therefore their optical properties are directly affected by static and dynamic properties of ligand anions. The magnesium, gallate MgGa2O4 is a partially inverted spinel described as a AB2O4 material with two possible positions for A2+ and B3+ cations. Polycrystalline MgGa2O4 : Co2+ samples were produced by solid-state reactions between ultra-pure raw oxides MgO, β-Ga2O3 and the desired CoCO3 quantities. Photoluminescence data at room temperature and 77 K of MgGa2O 4 polycrystalline samples doped with 0.1 and 1.0% of Co2+ are presented. The visible emission observed is attributed to the 4T1(4P) →4 A2( 4F) spin-allowed transition of Co2+ ions tetrahedrally coordinated by O2- ions. The photoluminescence intensity decreases with temperature, but 90% of the 77 K emission integrated intensity remains at room temperature. Moreover, from lifetime results we estimate that Co 2+ emission quantum efficiency is about 1.0 at room temperature. We also observe that between 0.1 and 1.0% of Co2+ the luminescence intensity decreases. For 1.0% of Co2+ the luminescence intensity is 37% of the obtained for 0.1%. This fact is attributed to non-radiative transfer processes of impurity ion relaxation that become competitive at 1.0% of Co 2+ and show that there is a strongly impurity-concentration luminescence dependence. We also observed that for the higher concentration the band, is slightly shifted to the infrared region. Due to low impurity ion concentration it would not be expected an energy transfer between Co 2+ ions, therefore non-radiative decay processes are responsible by temperature luminescence quenching. © 2008 American Institute of Physics.
Author Keywords: Ceramics; Co2+; Photoluminescence

Title: Diffusion and separation of CO2 and CH4 in Silicalite, C168 schwarzite, and IRMOF-1: A comparative study from molecular dynamics simulation
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117576, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Babarao, R., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117576, Singapore; Jiang, J., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117576, Singapore
Abstract: Recently we have investigated the storage and adsorption selectivity of CO2 and CH4 in three different classes of nanoporous materials - silicalite, IRMOF-1, and C168 schwarzite through Monte Carlo simulation (Babarao, R.; Hu, Z.; Jiang, J. Langmuir, 2007, 23, 659). In this work, the self-, corrected, and transport diffusivities of CO2 and CH4 in these materials are examined using molecular dynamics simulation. The activation energies at infinite dilution are evaluated from the Arrhenius fits to the diffusivities at various temperatures. As loading increases, the self-diffusivities in the three frameworks decrease as a result of the steric hindrance; the corrected diffusivities remain nearly constant or decrease approximately linearly depending on the adsorbate and framework; and the transport diffusivities generally increase except for CO2 in IRMOF-1. The correlation effects are identified to reduce from MFI, Cies to IRMOF-1, in accordance with the porosity increasing in the three frameworks. Predictions of self-, corrected, and transport diffusivities for pure CO 2 and CH4 from the Maxwell-Stefan formulation match the simulation results well. In a CO2/CH4 mixture, the self-diffusivities decreases with loading, and good agreement is found between simulated and predicted results. On the basis of the adsorption and self-diffusivity in the mixture, the permselectivity is found to be marginal in IRMOF-1, slightly enhanced in MFI, and greatest in C168 schwarzite. Although IRMOF-1 has the largest storage capacity for CH4 and CO 2, its selectivity is not satisfactory. © 2008 American Chemical Society.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Cobalt compounds; Separation; adsorption selectivity; Cobalt alloys

Title: Science & technology concentrates: Nanosizing improves hydrogen storage
Abstract: According to Cornelius P. Baldé, Krijn P. de Jong, et al. at Utrecht University, The Netherlands, for hydrogen storage applications, materials composed of nanometer-sized particles outperform samples with larger particles in terms of energetics and hydrogen-release (desorption) temperature. The study may lead to new forms of materials that are well suited for use in hydrogen-powered automobiles. The researchers developed wet synthesis methods that yield NaAlH4 particles measuring 1-10 μm, 19-30 nm, and 2-10 nm. The hydrogen-release temperature and activation energy decrease from 186°C and 116 kJ/mole for the larger particles to 70°C and 58 kJ/mole for the smaller particles.

Authors: Chibowski E., Holysz L., Jurak M.
Title: Effect of a lipolytic enzyme on wettability and topography of phospholipid layers deposited on solid support
Source title: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
Affiliations: Department of Interfacial Phenomena, Faculty of Chemistry, Maria Curie-Sklodowska University, 20031 Lublin, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Chibowski, E., Department of Interfacial Phenomena, Faculty of Chemistry, Maria Curie-Sklodowska University, 20031 Lublin, Poland; Holysz, L., Department of Interfacial Phenomena, Faculty of Chemistry, Maria Curie-Sklodowska University, 20031 Lublin, Poland; Jurak, M., Department of Interfacial Phenomena, Faculty of Chemistry, Maria Curie-Sklodowska University, 20031 Lublin, Poland
Abstract: The wetting properties of solid supported phospholipid DPPC (1,2-dipalmitoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine) films transferred by means of Langmuir-Blodgett and Langmuir-Schaefer techniques on hydrophilized glass from the surface of pure water, before and after modification with enzyme-phospholipase A2 (PLA2), were investigated. The surface free energy (wettability) of the films was evaluated on the basis of contact angle measurements of three probe liquids (water, formamide, diiodomethane). The film structure of the lipid layers was examined using atomic force microscope (AFM). The AFM images appeared to be helpful for better understanding of the free energy changes caused by the enzyme PLA2 action. The energy changes indicate that at room temperature DPPC mono- and bilayer is degraded within 5-10 min. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: AFM; DPPC; Phospholipase A2; Surface free energy
Index Keywords: Free energy; Langmuir Blodgett films; Phospholipids; Wetting; Langmuir-Schaefer techniques; Phospholipase; Surface free energy; Enzyme activity; dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine; formamide; methane; methylene iodide; phospholipase A2; phospholipid; water; article; atomic force microscopy; hysteresis; Langmuir Blodgett film; lipid bilayer; lipid storage; lipolysis; priority journal; room temperature; topography; wettability

Title: Optical transmission of the active power filter cooperating with Battery Energy Storage control system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Białystok Technical University, Department of Optical Radiation, Wiejska Street 45D, 15-359 Bialystok, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Kuźma, A., Białystok Technical University, Department of Optical Radiation, Wiejska Street 45D, 15-359 Bialystok, Poland; Zajkowski, M., Białystok Technical University, Department of Optical Radiation, Wiejska Street 45D, 15-359 Bialystok, Poland
Abstract: In the paper the battery energy storage system is presented. 40 kVA BES was installed in Electrical Drive and Power Electronics Department of Bialystok Technical University. The article presents the new way of control the battery energy storage through the active power filter. Because of the power coefficient cosφ decrease and input current deformation the battery energy storage system was equipped with active filter to current distortion elimination. The active power filter's control system uses the optical track which is based on optical fibre. Insensibility important is on the large electromagnetic field in the arrangement of control. This assures the optical system. The test of the implementation of the optical track was introduced in the arrangement IPM among the control system and inverter.
Author Keywords: Active power filter; Battery energy storage; Direct system; Fiber optic; Inverter; Optical track; WDM system

Title: Impedance spectroscopy of N-substituted oligo-oxyethylene polypyrrole films
Affiliations: Chemistry Group, Faculty of Engineering, Atilim University, 06836 Ankara, Turkey; Department of Chemistry, Middle East Technical University, 06531 Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Cihaner, A., Chemistry Group, Faculty of Engineering, Atilim University, 06836 Ankara, Turkey; Önal, A.M., Department of Chemistry, Middle East Technical University, 06531 Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: The electrochemical properties of neutral (dedoped) and oxidized (doped) poly(1,11-bis(1,1-pyrrole)-3,6,9-trioxaundecane) (poly-I) film electrodes were investigated using cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) techniques. Poly-I was deposited on glassy carbon electrode (GCE) from acetonitrile solution containing 5.0 × 10-3M 1,11-bis(1,1-pyrrole)-3,6,9-trioxaundecane (I) and 0.1M LiClO4 supporting electrolyte. Doped poly-I exhibits a single semicircle in its complex-capacitance plots, indicating a single dominant ion transport process, together with high capacitance values. These features make this polymer film a candidate for an energy storage material. Also, poly-I can be a candidate as a sensory material for the detection of Ag+ based on impedance parameters. © 2008 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy; Electrochemistry; Polyether; Polypyrrole; Sensor

Authors: Pykönen M., Sundqvist H., Kaukoniemi O.-V., Tuominen M., Lahti J., Fardim P., Toivakka M.
Title: Ageing effect in atmospheric plasma activation of paper substrates
Affiliations: Laboratory of Paper Coating and Converting, Center for Functional Materials, Åbo Akademi University, Finland; VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland, Finland; Institute of Paper Converting, Tampere University of Technology, Finland; Laboratory of Fibre and Cellulose Technology, Åbo Akademi University, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Pykönen, M., Laboratory of Paper Coating and Converting, Center for Functional Materials, Åbo Akademi University, Finland; Sundqvist, H., VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland, Finland; Kaukoniemi, O.-V., VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland, Finland; Tuominen, M., Institute of Paper Converting, Tampere University of Technology, Finland; Lahti, J., Institute of Paper Converting, Tampere University of Technology, Finland; Fardim, P., Laboratory of Fibre and Cellulose Technology, Åbo Akademi University, Finland; Toivakka, M., Laboratory of Paper Coating and Converting, Center for Functional Materials, Åbo Akademi University, Finland
Abstract: This work concerns the ageing effect of the atmospheric plasma and corona treatments when used to treat paper substrates. Pigment coated and surface sized papers were modified using two types of atmospheric plasma equipment; one at the pilot scale and one at the laboratory scale. In addition, the plasma treatments were compared to conventional corona treatment. Surface energy was estimated by contact angle measurements and surface chemistry by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as a function of the time during three months. The treatments increased surface energy and oxidation level of surface for both papers. The ageing effect could be detected only in the surface energy, whereas the oxidation level remained stable during the twelve weeks. The decay in surface energy was faster during the first weeks of storage and subsequently leveled off leading to a permanent change. The permanent change was explained as a contribution of oxygen containing polar molecular groups, which were detected by XPS. The ageing effect was suggested to originate from already existing polar molecular groups, which have rotated on the surface by plasma-related process and then rotate back into the material in time. A part of the decay was also explained by the plasma cleaning model, in which the ageing effect occurred through re-contamination. Paper is a multicomponent system, where the constituents that have the lowest surface energy were suggested to migrate to paper surfaces. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Corona; Durability; Paper; Plasma treatment; Surface energy; XPS
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Contact angle; Interfacial energy; Plasma applications; Surface treatment; Atmospheric plasma treatment; Paper substrate; Paper coating; Aging of materials; Contact angle; Interfacial energy; Paper coating; Plasma applications; Surface treatment; Aging; Contact Angle; Corona Discharge; Paper Products; Plasma; Substrates; Surface Energy; Surface Treatment

Title: Charging ahead
Authors with affiliations: Boothroyd, D.
Abstract: Ongoing advancements in the field of supercapacitors are making them a viable electric energy storage option, particularly in consumer electronics products and automotive industry. Texan company EEStor is developing an electric energy storage unit (EESU) based on ceramic supercapacitor with a barium-titanate dielectric. The company claims that its system has a specific energy of around 280Wh/kg, compared with about 120 for lithium-ion and 32 for lead gel batteries, and that it will outperform lithium ion batteries in terms of price, charge time, and safety. Lockheed Martin has signed a deal to use EEStor supercapacitors for military and homeland security applications. A team of researchers at the Cambridge University's Electronics Power and Energy Conversion (EPEC) Group has also developed nanoscale supercapacitors made from multiwalled carbon tubes. The key target for the EPEC group's supercapacitors is portable electronic devices, where they will offer much greater performance.

Title: Ghrelin: A new peptide regulating growth hormone release and food intake
Source title: International Journal of Biochemistry and Cell Biology
Affiliations: Laboratory of Biological Chemistry and Nutrition, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Vriese, C., Laboratory of Biological Chemistry and Nutrition, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belgium; Delporte, C., Laboratory of Biological Chemistry and Nutrition, Université Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Ghrelin, identified as an endogenous ligand for the growth hormone secretagogue receptor, is a 28 amino acid peptide hormone possessing an unusual octanoyl group on the serine in position 3, crucial for its biological activity. Ghrelin is predominantly produced by the stomach but also by many other tissues such as pituitary, hypothalamus, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, colon, lung, heart, pancreas, kidney, and testis. In addition to stimulation of GH release, ghrelin stimulates appetite and food intake, enhancing fat mass deposition and weight gain. Besides these main actions, ghrelin regulates gastric motility and acid secretion, exerts cardiovascular and anti-inflammatory effects, modulates cell proliferation and influences endocrine and exocrine pancreatic secretion, as well as glucose and lipid metabolism. Therefore, ghrelin agonists and antagonists might be valuable for some clinical aspects. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Appetite regulation; Energy homeostasis; Ghrelin; Metabolism
Index Keywords: fat; ghrelin; growth hormone; antiinflammatory activity; cardiovascular effect; cardiovascular function; cell proliferation; energy; food intake; gastrointestinal tract function; gene sequence; glucose metabolism; homeostasis; hormonal regulation; hormone release; human; lipid metabolism; lipid storage; metabolism; nonhuman; pancreas secretion; protein expression; short survey; stomach acid secretion; stomach motility; turnover time; weight gain; Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Eating; Energy Metabolism; Gene Expression Regulation; Ghrelin; Growth Hormone; Humans; Molecular Sequence Data

Title: Eagle Crest Energy Company; Notice of application accepted for filing and soliciting comments, protests, and motions to intervene
Abstract: Eagle Crest Energy Co has filed a hydroelectric application with FERC for the proposed Eagle Mountain Pumped Storage Project. The project would be located in Riverside County, CA. The proposed pumped storage project would include upper reservoir dams, with a storage capacity of 20,000 acre-ft and a normal water surface elevation of 2485 ft mean sea level (msl), a lower reservoir with storage capacity of 21,900 acre-ft and normal water surface elevation of 926 ft msl located within the East Pit of the inactive Eagle Mountain Mine, and a powerhouse containing four generating units having a total installed capacity of 1300 Mw. Deadline for filing comments, protests, and motions to intervene would be 60 days from the issuance date (5/8/2008) of this notice.

Title: Eagle Crest Energy Company; Notice of application accepted for filing and soliciting comments, protests, and motions to intervene
Abstract: On 3/3/2008, Eagle Crest Energy Co filed with FERC an application for a preliminary permit for the proposed Eagle Mountain Pumped Storage Project. It would be located in Riverside County, CA. The project would use federal land managed by the US Bureau of Land Management. The proposed pumped storage project would consist of two upper reservoir dams; a proposed upper reservoir; a proposed lower reservoir; proposed intake and outlet structures for both reservoirs; and a proposed upper "low head" pressure. The deadline for filing comments, protests, and motions to intervene is 60 days from the issuance date of this notice (4/30/2008).

Title: House SPR oil purchase hearing splits along party lines
Authors with affiliations: Snow, N.
Abstract: At the Apr. 24 US House committee hearing regarding on the continuation of oil purchase for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR), democrats and republicans have different analyzation. According to democrats, the purchasing suspension of SPR would effectively ease upward price pressure via sending more oil onto global markets instead of into storage. A thing that republicans disagreed, where it responded that the authorization of leasing with appropriate environmental safeguards withing the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and on more of the Outer Continental shelf would be even more effective. There are witnesses that offered recommendations to Bush administration to manage the SPR more effectively. Among the recommendations offered range from generating more research and development funding, and sweet crude in the reserve.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Energy policy; Petroleum industry; Petroleum reservoirs; Purchasing; continental shelf; energy policy; hydrocarbon reserve; hydrocarbon reservoir; oil supply; petroleum; price dynamics; research and development; Alaska; Arctic National Wildlife Refuge; North America; United States

Authors: Morgen P., Henriksen B., Kyrping D.
Title: Ion etching methods for depth profiling of complex three-dimensional samples in combination with scanning Auger electron microscopy
Affiliations: Institut for Fysik og Kemi, University of Southern Denmark, Campusvej 55, DK-5230 Odense M, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Morgen, P., Institut for Fysik og Kemi, University of Southern Denmark, Campusvej 55, DK-5230 Odense M, Denmark; Henriksen, B., Institut for Fysik og Kemi, University of Southern Denmark, Campusvej 55, DK-5230 Odense M, Denmark; Kyrping, D., Institut for Fysik og Kemi, University of Southern Denmark, Campusvej 55, DK-5230 Odense M, Denmark
Abstract: Ion etching of surfaces combined with detection of secondary events (particles or radiation emitted) are used for depth profiling of samples with interesting features at-, near-, or somewhat below the surface. These methods are destructive and relatively slow, and compete with non-destructive methods like Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy in the scanning electron microscope or angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, which are non-destructive and relatively faster methods. In this work we have concentrated on the use of noble gas ion sputtering with low-energy beams in combination with electron excited Auger electron spectroscopy and imaging for analysis of nanostructured and microstructured samples. No attempt will be made here to justify this method over the other methods, as their relative merits depend on the nature of the sample and the problem at hand. We have thus chosen to study samples and problems for which this technique would be obvious to use. This work is also aimed at providing practical standards and guidelines ("metrology") for the use of the technique in the context of industrial nanotechnology. The use of Auger electron spectroscopy instead of photoemission spectroscopy is preferred for laterally non-uniform samples due to the presently better resolution capabilities of electron beams and narrower information depths of typical Auger electron transitions. The use of Auger electrons for concentration sampling, and low-energy beams of noble gas ions for sputtering, reduces the adverse influence of atomic mixing. In this report two systems are intensively studied with sputter profiling in combination with Auger electron spectroscopy and scanning electron imaging: a hard disk and a surface of a stainless-steel sample. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Auger electron spectroscopy; Hard disk; Imaging; Passivated surface layer; Sputter profiling
Index Keywords: Auger electron spectroscopy; Hard disk storage; Imaging techniques; Sputter deposition; Passivated surface layer; Sputter profiling; Etching

Title: PowdermatriX
Abstract: Powdermatrix Technology Translators produced a report, 'The Future of Power Generation-The Role of Particulate Materials', assessing future development opportunities for particulate materials and products in the power generation, transformation, distribution, and storage industries. The report shows that around 80% of new generation capacity will be based on fossil fuel combustion technologies. These installations will require increased efficiency and reduced emissions. Further deployment of fuel cell technologies will revolve around the need to reduce manufacturing costs and enhance reproducibility, consisting of performance and scale-up to larger output devices. It is expected that there will be a strong incentive to extend the lifetimes of existing installations. Effective strategies for repair, refurbishment and retrofitted enhancements will be of increasing value. Ceramic materials and processing routes for solid oxide fuel cell electrolytes should be investigated to reduce manufacturing costs, increase reliability and consistency of performance.
Index Keywords: Manufacturing costs; Reproducibility; Solid oxide fuel cell electrolytes; Ceramic materials; Combustion; Electric energy storage; Fossil fuels; Particles (particulate matter); Particulate emissions; Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC); Electric power generation

Title: Opening up opportunities in system designs
Authors with affiliations: Fronauer, W.
Abstract: Wolf Fornauer, Marketing Manager at Japanese Firm look at the reasons for Ferroelectric Random Access Memory (FRAM), is becoming increasingly popular with system designers. The combination of the features of RAM and ROM/EEPROM functions, together with higher write/read speed and lower power consumption, opens up new possibilities for system design. This type of memory is based on a thin film with ferroelectric properties, where a condenser with ferroelectric dielectric medium is used, meaning the structure of a memory cell is similar to that of a DRAM cell. The properties of FRAM make it suitable for application in high data volumes frequently with low energy. The FRAM offers an almost unlimited write life cycle, so unlike with other non-volatile memories, the early appearance of wear and tear will not be a problem.
Index Keywords: Data volume; Dielectric medium; DRAM cells; Ferroelectric property; Ferroelectric random access memories; Japanese firms; Low energies; Lower-power consumption; Marketing manager; Memory cell; Non-volatile memories; System design; System designers; Wear and tear; Cell membranes; Ferroelectricity; Random access storage; Systems analysis; Ferroelectric devices

Title: Cutting carbon emissions - some implications
Authors with affiliations: Oam, J.R.
Abstract: The government of Australia is planning to reduce carbon dioxide emission by 60% by 2050 despite considering the fact that it has 75% dependency on coal for electricity generation. The coal mining industry and many coal-based electricity plant can be shutdown with the implementation of government's decision. The government is encouraging the use of natural gas fueled power stations due to its less emission during electricity generation. Another method to reduce the emission is to capture and storage of carbon by injection into the earth. Australia is taking effective measures to use renewables energy sources, wind, and solar power for electricity generation. Australia need to use and consumes nuclear electricity as it has large resource of uranium, which can also play a significant role to reduce carbon dioxide emission.

Title: UK: Atomic momentum
Authors with affiliations: Brower, D.
Abstract: A new generation of nuclear power stations is at the heart of the UK's plans to cut carbon emissions and make its energy supplies more secure. All but one of the country's existing nuclear power stations, which supply about 20% of the country's electricity will be mothballed by 2023. The government will not put an "artificial cap" on the nuclear's share of generation and it ought to increase beyond 20% in future. The big nuclear companies have already begun buying up capacity from National Grid, the country's transmission-system operator. With no real plans to increase the country's grid capacity, the pre-emptive buying of wires by nuclear generators will make it increasingly difficult for wind farms and other renewable projects to challenge nuclear. In natural gas, however, the government is talking about expanding the network and wants to encourage new infrastructure, including for LNG imports and offshore storage.

Title: Energy policy: Shell calls for profound change in energy policy
Abstract: A sustainable energy future is achievable, but there must be "profound change" in the way energy is supplied and used, according to Royal Dutch Shell. Shell's latest thesis on the long-term future of energy flows - a document entitled Shell energy scenarios to 2050 - outlines two cases, referred to as Scramble and Blueprints. In the first, policymakers pay little attention to more efficient energy use until supplies are tight. The problem of rising greenhouse gas emissions is not seriously tackled until there are significant climate shocks. In Blueprints - which Shell says offers the better hope for a sustainable future - local actions begin to address the problems of economic development, energy security and environmental pollution. A price is applied to a critical mass of emissions giving a "huge stimulus" to the development of clean-energy technologies, such as carbon capture and storage, and energy efficiency measures.

Title: Environment: Saudi oil minister hails solar and CCS, but rubbishes biofuels
Abstract: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Ali al-Naimi, has outlined the kingdom's growing interest in alternative technologies, such as solar power and carbon capture and storage, but not before attacking recent policies promoting biofuels. In a speech at the International Oil Summit in Paris, al-Naimi claimed that Saudi Arabia has no prejudice against such types of energy, but criticized governments for offering subsidies to the biofuels industry and setting targets for their utilization. Al-Naimi highlighted the role Saudi Arabia plays in meeting the world's energy needs through its petroleum industry, with oil production and refining capacity both undergoing significant expansion; $90 billion is to be spent over the coming 5 yr on oil projects. Oil output will rise to 12.5 million bpd in 2009, spare production capacity will be maintained at 1.5-2 million bpd. Downstream, refining capacity is being doubled from 3 to 6 million bpd.

Title: Dynamic simulation of electrostatically controlled MEMS-capacitors in the operating temperature range (293...323) K
Affiliations: Kharkov Aviation Institute, Kharkov, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Kolpakov, F.F., Kharkov Aviation Institute, Kharkov, Ukraine; Borzyak, N.G., Kharkov Aviation Institute, Kharkov, Ukraine
Abstract: A dynamic model of the microelectromechanical (MEMS) capacitor with electrostatic control has been proposed. This model is based on the A.A. Kharkevich multisided transducer theory with due regard for the thermal impact. A two-electrode capacitive MEMS-transducer was simulated and dynamic relationships of the electrode travel and capacitance (as well as the actuation time of the device) were determined at ambient temperatures in the range (293...323) K. The dynamic characteristic of mechanical resistance of the system has been also derived and analyzed with due regard for the working temperature and parameters of MEMS-capacitor. © Allerton Press, Inc. 2008.

Title: Environmental: Symposium highlights future energy challenges, opportunities
Abstract: Escalating oil and gas prices, along with the global challenge of climate change, have spurred new generations of scientists to search for alternative energy sources. A national panel of experts gathered at the AIChE Spring Meeting in New Orleans to present a comprehensive overview of the current status, limitations, and future challenges of several significant renewable energy sources. The review, which included research from multiple scientific and engineering fields, covered solar and nuclear energy, the hydrogen economy, electrical energy storage, and catalysis for transportation fuels.

Authors: Nagashima K., Seino H., Miyazaki Y., Arai Y., Sakai N., Murakami M.
Title: Force density of magnetic bearings using superconducting coils and bulk superconductors
Source title: Quarterly Report of RTRI (Railway Technical Research Institute) (Japan)
Affiliations: Cryogenic Systems Laboratory, Maglev Systems Technology Division; Superconductivity Research Laboratory; Shibaura Institute of Technology
Authors with affiliations: Nagashima, K., Cryogenic Systems Laboratory, Maglev Systems Technology Division; Seino, H., Cryogenic Systems Laboratory, Maglev Systems Technology Division; Miyazaki, Y., Cryogenic Systems Laboratory, Maglev Systems Technology Division; Arai, Y., Cryogenic Systems Laboratory, Maglev Systems Technology Division; Sakai, N., Superconductivity Research Laboratory; Murakami, M., Shibaura Institute of Technology
Abstract: Stable levitation or suspension of a heavy object in mid-air can be realized using a combination of a permanent magnet and a bulk superconductor with high critical current density, in that the force density has reached 100 kN/m2. The superconducting flywheel system for energy storage is attractive due to a great reduction in the rotational loss of the bearings So long as a permanent magnet is used as a magnetic source, however, the electromagnetic force (EMF) is essentially limited by its field strength. In order to overcome such a limitation, we employed a superconducting coil / magnet as a magnetic source and studied the EMF characteristics of bulk superconductors in high magnetic fields. We also measured the EMF between a bulk superconductor and a specially designed superconducting coil having a high field gradient, and confirmed that the EMF reached 9,000 N (force density: 1,190 k N/m2).
Author Keywords: Bulk superconductor; Energy storage; Flywheel; Force density; Magnetic bearing; Superconducting coil

Title: New lamps for old to help the environment
Abstract: Aside from manufacturing techniques, smarter sourcing, storage, and distribution system, lighting is often a prime candidate for improvement. It makes a powerful contribution to the ambience of any space and essential to assure the safety of the workforce. There are new improved lamps to be used such as MASTER TL-D 70W Color 80 that provides up to 40% energy savings. Other includes Philips MASTER TL-D XTRA and EXTREME, and Philips TTX400 system. The control of lighting is also essential that enable the end-user to fine-tune the way the lighting system operates on a daily basis. These new lighting technologies offer flexibility and optimum performance as well as the benefit to reduced operational costs.

Title: Intelligent middleware infrastructure aids automated demand response
Abstract: NetApp, a provider of storage and data-management solutions, California, has utilized lucrative incentive-based energy-reduction programs of Pacific Gas and Electric Co. (PG&E), for automated demand response (ADR) and reduction of energy use. The company focused on interoperability provided by open standards to create interfaces for its disparate building-automation systems, metering systems, and uninterruptible power supply. The multi-Protocol Exchange (MPX) integration framework normalizes both Internet and legacy serial-based protocols, allowing intraprotocol communication. The middleware includes intelligent layer that provides custom logic and advanced math between integrated building systems and change-of-value notification to maximize data-management efficiency. The intelligent middleware device brings building systems and enterprise services together through communication, data, integration, and services.

Title: Solution to an energy riddle?
Abstract: Ultracapacitors may be able to bridge the gap between batteries and capacitors because like batteries, they don't rely on static charge and can store energy for a long period. Positively charged ions gather on the surface of the negatively charged electrode, and negative ions group on the surface of the positive electrode. The ionic layers are very close to the surfaces of the electrodes and run parallel with them. careful design can increase the surface area and thus the storage capacity without increasing the volume, which means an ultracapacitors has the endurance of a battery and the speed of a capacitor. A company called EEStor is developing an ultracapacitor that it claims can store high levels of energy using a special insulator called barium titanate rather than an electrolyte. It has signed an agreement with Lockheed-Martin for exclusive rights to integrate and market the product in military and homeland security applications.

Authors: Gatti J.B., De Castilho Queiroz G., Garcia E.E.C.
Title: Recycling of aluminum can in terms of Life Cycle Inventory (LCI)
Source title: International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment
Affiliations: CETEA - Packaging Technology Center, ITAL - Food Technology Institute, P.O. Box 139, Campinas, SP 13073-001, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Gatti, J.B., CETEA - Packaging Technology Center, ITAL - Food Technology Institute, P.O. Box 139, Campinas, SP 13073-001, Brazil; De Castilho Queiroz, G., CETEA - Packaging Technology Center, ITAL - Food Technology Institute, P.O. Box 139, Campinas, SP 13073-001, Brazil; Garcia, E.E.C., CETEA - Packaging Technology Center, ITAL - Food Technology Institute, P.O. Box 139, Campinas, SP 13073-001, Brazil
Abstract: Background, Aims and Scope. Life Cycle Assessment is a technique for evaluating the environmental performance of a given product by: identifying and quantifying the energy and raw materials used in its manufacturing process, as well as the emissions of pollutants to water, soil, and air inherent in this production, use and disposal, and evaluating the environmental impact associated with the use of energy and materials and the emissions of pollutants, thus identifying opportunities to improve the system in order to optimize the environmental performance of the product. CETEA (Packaging Technology Center) has conducted a Life Cycle Assessment - LCA study of aluminum can with emphasis in life cycle inventory, collecting data for the reference years 2000-2002. The goal of this paper is to present part of this complete study, focusing the influence of aluminium recycling rate on the Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) of aluminum beverage cans in Brazil. Methods. The adopted methodology was based on the recommendations of SETAC - Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry and the ISO 14040 Standard, approved by the Sub-Committee 05 of the Environmental Administration Technical Committee, TC-207, from ISO - INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR STANDARDIZATION [1,2]. Data storage and modeling were performed by employing the PIRA Environmental Management System - PEMS [3]. Results. Taking into account the impact categories adopted in this study, it has been shown that recycling helps to improve the aluminium can environmental profile measured as LCI data. Discussion. For the transformed aluminium products, the recycling rate affects the values of the environmental parameters inventoried, but not in the same proportion, since the contribution of other stages of the product system life cycle and the recycling process remain unchanged, including the yield of this process. In general, the recycling balance is always positive due to the importance of the stages that precede the packaging production and the problem of increasing the municipal waste volume. Conclusions. The advantages of the recycling are obviously concentrated on the inventoried parameters related to the primary aluminum production and to the package disposal. The verified benefits of the recycling increase with the recycling rate enhancement. However, the effects on the inventory do not have the same magnitude of the recycling rate. This happens due to the relative contributions of the other life cycle stages, such as the transportation and sheet or can production. In agreement with the presented results, it is possible to conclude that the aluminum can recycling reduces part of the consumption of natural resources and the emissions associated to the stages previous to the production of the packaging. The parameters specifically related to the stage of aluminum production suffer reduction directly proportional to the increase of the recycling rate. In this way, all of the efforts made to increase the recycling rate will have a positive contribution to the LCI of the aluminum can. Recommendations. It is worth pointing out that LCA studies are iterative and dynamic. The data can always be refined, substituted or complemented with updated information in order to improve the representativeness of the analyzed sector. Perspectives. From this study, the aluminum sector in Brazil is able to quantify the benefits of future actions for environmental improvement of the Brazilian aluminum industry, as well as to contribute technically to Environmental Labeling initiatives regarding aluminum products. © 2008 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Aluminum; Brazil; Can; Electricity; Energy; Environment; Inventory; Life cycle assessment; Recycling

Title: Energy-efficient mechanical pulps - A chance for European paper producers
Authors with affiliations: Muenster, H.
Abstract: Wood and electricity prices are permanently rising. Fibre costs are therefore more than ever determining the competitiveness of papermaking. Unavoidable losses in the collection and necessary processing of wastepaper necessitates on average a 30-40 % fresh fibre inflow. This fresh virgin fibre input should preferably be in the form of mechanical pulps because of their high yield, several functional advantages, better recyclability, lower investment costs and suitability for integrated, even smaller production units, provided that the energy requirements are significantly reduced. In conventional mechanical pulping processes only a few percent of the applied mechanical energy are used for actual fibre separation, flexibilisation, fibrillation and surface creation. The remainder is converted into heat. The potential for efficiency improvements should therefore be substantial. Latest developments in refining and grinding are presented, especially methods for mechanical and chemical pretreatment (RT/RTF) of chips in combination with high intensity processes (RTS-TMP) as well as results from high temperature low consistency refining. Options for efficient steam recovery are described and an attempt is made to show where the R&D work is heading to.

Title: Radiative transfer within a cylindrical cavity with diffusely/specularly reflecting inner walls containing an array of tubular absorbers
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland; Solar Technology Laboratory, Paul Scherrer Institute, 5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Melchior, T., Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland; Steinfeld, A., Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland, Solar Technology Laboratory, Paul Scherrer Institute, 5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: Monte Carlo radiative transfer analysis is applied to a cylindrical cavity-receiver containing an array of high-temperature tubular absorbers directly exposed to concentrated solar power entering through a spectrally selective window. The cavity walls are assumed either diffusely or specularly reflective. The relative dimensions, the number of tubes, and their position are optimized for maximum energy transfer efficiency or maximum absorber temperature. A single-tube absorber operating at 2000 K performs best when located at 60% relative distance to the cavity's aperture. Higher absorber temperatures are attained for a specularly reflective cavity that serves as internal infrared mirror but at the expense of lower energy transfer efficiencies. In contrast, diffuse reflecting cavity walls promote a more uniform temperature distribution around the tubular absorber. Decreasing the window-to-cavity areas ratio further results in an increase of the absorber temperature, which peaks for an optimum absorber-to-cavity radii ratio. This optimum ratio shifts to lower values for multiple-tube absorbers. However, the average absorber temperature is not significantly affected by using multiple-tube absorbers of constant total cross sectional area. Copyright © 2008 by ASME.

Title: EPRI takes on low-level waste disposal issues
Affiliations: LLW Department, EPRI; EPRI; DW James Consulting LLC
Authors with affiliations: Tran, P., LLW Department, EPRI; James, D., EPRI, DW James Consulting LLC
Abstract: The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) is continually investigating the alternatives to the present US low-level radioactive waste (LLW) disposal classification criteria, which are governed by 10 CFR 61. The work undertaken by EPRI and the Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI) is focused on developing a better understanding of the LLW source term from nuclear power plants. The weighted average classification basis is about 10% of the Class A waste disposal limit, which assumes averaging over all of the wastes without consideration of waste generation. EPRI plan is aimed to increase the radioactive waste disposal to 83, 000 ft3, leaving only 5000 ft3 for onsite storage. EPRI investigation also aimed to address potential issues related to nonutility radioactive wastes and investigate the impacts of employing other disposal models such as International Atomic Energy Agency disposal scheme.

Title: Record attendance for waste management's first show in Phoenix
Abstract: Waste Management 2008 was held in February 24-28, 2008, in Phoenix, Arizona, to discuss the management of nuclear waste. James Rispoli, assistant secretary for the US Department of Energy's Environmental Management (EM) division, informed that EM has completed many smaller projects at larger facilities, while facing various challenges. Dale Klein, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission chairman, stated that NRC has accomplished task of reducing nuclear waste volumes and has done a good job of cutting waste generation. Klein acknowledged that the area of greatest need is low-level waste storage and disposal and also expressed his concern about the effects that is posed by the budget cuts on the Yucca Mountain project. Steve Creamer, president of Energy Solutions, focused his presentation on working together for a nuclear reality and the two major issues being faced by the world that include energy security and global warming.

Title: July 1, 2008 - Just another day in the life of low-level radwaste generators
Affiliations: Studsvik Inc.; WCS
Authors with affiliations: Harrison, J., Studsvik Inc.; Cronshaw, D., WCS
Abstract: A Studsvik-Radioactive waste Control Specialist (WCS) plan aims to address the storage and disposal problems of low-level radioactive waster disposal (LLW) generators by creating a new long-term storage facility in Texas by July 1, 2008. Studsvik will use its Thermal Organic Reduction (THOR) process to volumetrically reduce the volume of LLW by 5 and stabilize it by removing organics and physically bonding the radioactivity of the remaining material to the reformed residue. The commercial aspects of the Studsvik-WCS plan aims to take the legal and economic responsibility for waste disposal. The primary purpose of the facility is to receive radioactively contaminated organic waste, reduce mass and volume utilizing THOR process, and package the volume/weight-reduce waste residue. Studsvik and WCS are also committed to nuclear energy and present innovative and value-added waste management services to LLW generators.

Title: Yucca mountain: Healthy or on its deathbed?
Authors with affiliations: Mallay, J.F.
Abstract: The US Regulatory Commission's 2008 Regulatory Information Conference (RIC) discussed various presentations over the Yukka Mountain project. Tina Seely, a reporter for Bloomberg News, gave the presentation providing an objective media perspective on the major issues related to the Yukka Mountain. Other notable issues included the transportation of spent fuel to the repository and the importance to many state officials of disposing of spent fuel from plants that are already closed. Steve Kraft of the Nuclear Energy Institute, addressed the broader subjects and emphasized the need for a three-step process that includes interim storage, reprocessing of spent fuels, and final disposal in a geologic repository. Marty Malsch, a partner with Egan, Fitzpatrick & Malsch PLLC raised various issues including the lack of definition for the conduct of the mandatory hearing, use of aging facility, adequacy of physical security, and the unrealistic use of titanium drip shields.

Authors: Liu J.C.P., Tse C.K., Poon N.K., Pong M.H., Lai Y.M.
Title: Synthesis of general impedance with simple dc/dc converters for power processing applications
Source title: International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; PowerELab Limited, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong; Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong; Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hunghom, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Liu, J.C.P., Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong, PowerELab Limited, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong; Tse, C.K., Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hunghom, Hong Kong; Poon, N.K., PowerELab Limited, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong; Pong, M.H., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong; Lai, Y.M., Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: A general impedance synthesizer using a minimum number of switching converters is studied in this paper. We begin with showing that any impedance can be synthesized by a circuit consisting of only two simple power converters, one storage element (e.g. capacitor) and one dissipative element (e.g. resistor) or power source. The implementation of such a circuit for synthesizing any desired impedance can be performed by (i) programming the input current given the input voltage such that the desired impedance function is achieved, (ii) controlling the amount of power dissipation (generation) in the dissipative element (source) so as to match the required active power of the impedance to be synthesized. Then, the instantaneous power will be automatically balanced by the storage element. Such impedance synthesizers find a lot of applications in power electronics. For instance, a resistance synthesizer can be used for power factor correction (PFC), a programmable capacitor or inductor synthesizer (comprising small high-frequency converters) can be used for control applications. Title: Analysis: Praise for Canadian CCS plans at oil sands
Abstract: Canadian plans to force all future oil sands projects and coal-fired power plants to include carbon capture and storage technology have been praised by the UK's energy minister Malcolm Wicks as "far-sighted". From 2012 onwards, all new oil sands projects and coal-fired power plants will have to capture their CO2 emissions and inject them underground. Canada will not be able to meet the targets of the Kyoto agreement, which require it to cut greenhouse gas emissions 20% below 1990 levels by 2020. Instead, the Canadian government wants to cut emissions 20% from 2006 levels by 2020.

Authors: Knapp A.C., Todesco L., Török M., Beier K., Krähenbühl S.
Title: Effect of carnitine deprivation on carnitine homeostasis and energy metabolism in mice with systemic carnitine deficiency
Affiliations: Division of Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, Department of Research, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Institute of Anatomy and Embryology, University of Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, University Hospital, CH-4031 Basel, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Knapp, A.C., Division of Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, Department of Research, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Todesco, L., Division of Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, Department of Research, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Török, M., Division of Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, Department of Research, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Beier, K., Institute of Anatomy and Embryology, University of Basel, Basel, Switzerland; Krähenbühl, S., Division of Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, Department of Research, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland, Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology, University Hospital, CH-4031 Basel, Switzerland
Abstract: Background/Aims: Juvenile visceral steatosis (jvs-/-) mice lack the activity of the carnitine transporter OCTN2 and are dependent on carnitine substitution. The effects of carnitine deprivation on carnitine homeostasis and energy metabolism are not known in jvs-/- mice. Methods: jvs-/- mice were studied 3, 6 and 10 days after carnitine deprivation, and compared to jvs-/- mice substituted with carnitine, wild-type (jvs+/+) and jvs+/- mice. Carnitine concentrations were assessed radioenzymatically. Results: Compared to wild-type mice, carnitine-treated jvs-/- mice had decreased plasma β-hydroxybutyrate levels and showed hepatic fat accumulation. The carnitine levels in plasma, liver and skeletal muscle were decreased by 58, 16 and 17%, respectively. After ten days of carnitine deprivation, the plasma carnitine concentration had fallen by 87% (to 2.3 μmol/l) and the tissue carnitine levels by ≈50% compared to carnitine-treated jvs-/- mice. Carnitine deprivation was associated with a further drop in plasma β-hydroxybutyrate and increased hepatic fat. Skeletal muscle glycogen stores decreased and lactate levels increased with carnitine deprivation, whereas tissue ATP levels were maintained. Conclusions: In jvs-/- mice, tissue carnitine stores are more resistant than carnitine plasma concentrations to carnitine deprivation. Metabolic changes (liver steatosis and loss of muscle glycogen stores) appear also early after carnitine deprivation. Copyright © 2008 S. Karger AG.

Authors: Vaikousi H., Biliaderis C.G., Koutsoumanis K.P.
Title: Development of a microbial time/temperature indicator prototype for monitoring the microbiological quality of chilled foods
Affiliations: Department of Food Science and Technology, School of Agriculture, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece; Laboratory of Food Hygiene and Microbiology, School of Agriculture, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece; Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Food Science and Technology, School of Agriculture, Thessaloniki, 54124, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Vaikousi, H., Department of Food Science and Technology, School of Agriculture, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece; Biliaderis, C.G., Department of Food Science and Technology, School of Agriculture, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece; Koutsoumanis, K.P., Laboratory of Food Hygiene and Microbiology, School of Agriculture, Aristotle University, Thessaloniki, Greece, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Food Science and Technology, School of Agriculture, Thessaloniki, 54124, Greece
Abstract: A time/temperature indicator (TTI) system based on the growth and metabolic activity of a Lactobacillus sakei strain was developed for monitoring food quality throughout the chilled-food chain. In the designed system, an irreversible color change of a chemical chromatic indicator (from red to yellow) progressively occurs due to the pH decline that results from microbial growth and metabolism in a selected medium. The relation of the TTI response (color change) to the growth and metabolic activity (glucose consumption, lactic acid production, pH decrease) of L. sakei was studied. In addition, the temperature dependence of the TTI kinetics was investigated isothermally in the range of 0 to 16°C and modeled with a system of differential equations. At all temperatures tested, the pH and color changes of the TTI system followed closely the growth of L. sakei, with the endpoint (the time at which a distinct visual color change to the final yellow was observed) of the TTI coinciding with a population level of 107 to 108 CFU/ml. The endpoint decreased from 27 days at 0°C to 2.5 days at 16°C, yielding an activation energy of 97.7 kJ/mol, which was very close to the activation energy of the L. sakei growth rate in the TTI substrate (103.2 kJ/mol). Furthermore, experiments conducted on the effect of the inoculum level showed a negative linear relationship between the level of L. sakei inoculated in the system medium and the endpoint of the TTI. For example, the endpoint at 8°C ranged from 6 to 2 days for inoculum levels of 101 and 106 CFU/ml, respectively. This relationship allows the easy adjustment of the TTI endpoint at a certain temperature according to the shelf life of the food product of concern by using an appropriate inoculum level of L. sakei. The microbial TTI prototype developed in the present study could be used as an effective tool for monitoring shelf life during the distribution and storage of food products that are spoiled primarily by lactic acid bacteria or other bacteria exhibiting similar kinetic responses and spoilage potentials. Apart from the low cost, the main advantage of the proposed TTI is that its response closely matches the loss of the quality of a food product by simulating the microbial spoilage process in particular environments. Title: CCS: Saviour or smokescreen?
Abstract: The assessment report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) suggests that climate change is processing so fast, but CCS will arrive too late to make a real contribution in time. Otway, the world's first real test of geosequestration under Australian conditions, and vital to the development of carbon capture and storage technology verify the process is practical, and monitors where the CO2 is being transported to and stored. The resurging interest in coal-fired power both from well-developed countries keen to reduce their reliance on imported energy, such as Australia, the UK and the US, and from developing countries such as China and India, gives the CCS debate all the more urgency. Oakley accuses energy companies of using the promise of future CCS as a convenient mechanism ensuring those power plants are approved.

Title: Liquor is quicker
Authors with affiliations: Wright, R.
Abstract: The energy storage in the form of methanol in place of hydrogen can end the dependence on the fossil fuels and transform carbon dioxide from a global-warming liability into an essential raw material. George A Olah, the winner of the 1994 Noble prize for the Chemistry, in his 2006 work ' Beyond Oil and Gas: The Methanol Economy' has argued that using methanol in place of hydrogen will be faster way of reducing the dependence on fossil fuels. Methanol is a liquid fuel and so can be used in an internal combustion engine and distributed using the current refueling infrastructure. Methanol has a higher octane rating than gasoline which makes it ideal for the downsized concepts OEMs are introducing. Methanol burns with a near-invisible flame, but the flame can be extinguished with water whereas a gasoline or diesel fire cannot. The use of methanol to replace the gasoline can reduce the primary transport fuel, death, injuries and property damage by 90 to 95 per cent.

Title: A larger role for microgrids
Authors with affiliations: Venkataramanan, G.; Marnay, C.
Abstract: Microgrids are well suited to play a significant role in the future evolution of energy service provision of electricity. The amount of electricity consumption per capita and the percentage of population with access to grid electricity indicate the structure of the economies. Microgrids allow to generate devices from several primary energy sources, often renewable, along with storage devices and controlled loads that operate in an autonomous fashion. They compliment and participate as a functional unit within the existing centralized legacy grid having inhibited expansion. They may be entirely technology neutral and accommodate diverse sources, including solar, wind, conventional fossil fuel, and storage devices. Microgrids may also play vital role in developing along diverse lines for several applications and equally may function under quite diverse business models and arrangements with the legacy grid.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric power utilization; Electric variables control; Renewable energy resources; Controlled loads; Energy services; Microgrids; Electric power distribution

Authors: Kroposki B., Lasseter R., Ise T., Morozumi S., Papathanassiou S., Hatziargyriou N.
Title: Making microgrids work
Authors with affiliations: Kroposki, B.; Lasseter, R.; Ise, T.; Morozumi, S.; Papathanassiou, S.; Hatziargyriou, N.
Abstract: Distributed energy resources (DER), such as distributed generation (DG) and distributed storage (DS), which are sources of energy located near local loads, should be properly operated in the electrical distribution system to make it able to offer several advantages, including improved reliability. Microgrids, systems that have at least one distributed energy resources and associated loads, can be made to work properly by opening an upstream switch and making distributed energy resource (DER) able to carry the load on islanded section. This involves maintenance of suitable voltage and frequency levels for all islanded loads. Power flow analysis of island scenarios should be carried out for ensuring that proper voltage regulation is maintained and to prove that the DER can handle inrush during 'starting' of the island. Microgrids can also benefit local utilities by offering dispatchable load to be used during peak power conditions.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric power transmission; Reliability analysis; Distributed energy resources (DER); Electrical distribution systems; Microgrids; Energy resources

Title: Production of renewable polymers from crop plants
Affiliations: Département de Biologie Moléculaire Végétale, Université de Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Van Beilen, J.B., Département de Biologie Moléculaire Végétale, Université de Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Poirier, Y., Département de Biologie Moléculaire Végétale, Université de Lausanne, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Plants produce a range of biopolymers for purposes such as maintenance of structural integrity, carbon storage, and defense against pathogens and desiccation. Several of these natural polymers are used by humans as food and materials, and increasingly as an energy carrier. In this review, we focus on plant biopolymers that are used as materials in bulk applications, such as plastics and elastomers, in the context of depleting resources and climate change, and consider technical and scientific bottlenecks in the production of novel or improved materials in transgenic or alternative crop plants. The biopolymers discussed are natural rubber and several polymers that are not naturally produced in plants, such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, fibrous proteins and poly-amino acids. In addition, monomers or precursors for the chemical synthesis of biopolymers, such as 4-hydroxybenzoate, itaconic acid, fructose and sorbitol, are discussed briefly. © 2008 The Authors.

Title: Decomposition of currents in three- and four-wire systems
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town 7701, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Malengret, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town 7701, South Africa; Gaunt, C.T., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town 7701, South Africa
Abstract: Various methods of instantaneous decomposing of three-phase currents in three- and four-wire systems for the purpose of instantaneous compensation without energy storage are reviewed, analyzed, and compared. It is found that the method of Akagi et al. and other equivalent methods are optimum in the three- and four-wire systems where the neutral current is constrained to be zero after compensation, whereas the more general method of Depenbrock et al. is optimum in the four-wire systems where the neutral current after compensation is not restricted. Furthermore, both methods can be expressed in a simpler equation if the correct "null" voltage reference is used. The equation is shown to be optimum through the mathematical properties of vector space. The orthogonal instantaneous nonactive current components are accordingly identified. The required compensating currents are compared. © 2008 IEEE.

Authors: Hemmeryckx B., Van Bree R., Van Hoef B., Vercruysse L., Lijnen H.R., Verhaeghe J.
Title: Adverse adipose phenotype and hyperinsulinemia in gravid mice deficient in placental growth factor
Affiliations: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Center for Molecular and Vascular Biology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, U.Z. Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Hemmeryckx, B., Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Van Bree, R., Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Van Hoef, B., Center for Molecular and Vascular Biology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Vercruysse, L., Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Lijnen, H.R., Center for Molecular and Vascular Biology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Verhaeghe, J., Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Health Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, 3000 Leuven, Belgium, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, U.Z. Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Pregnancy-induced metabolic changes are regulated by signals from an expanded adipose organ. Placental growth factor (PlGF), acting through vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-1, may be among those signals. There is a steep rise in circulating PlGF during normal pregnancy, which is repressed in gravidas who develop preeclampsia. PlGF-deficiency in mice impairs adipose vascularization and development. Here we studied young-adult PlGF-deficient (PlGF-/-) and wild-type mice on a high-fat diet in the nongravid state and at embryonic day (E) 13.5 or E18.5 of gestation. Litter size and weight were normal, but E18.5 placentas were smaller in PlGF-/- pregnancies. PlGF-/- mice showed altered intraadipose dynamics, with the following: 1) less blood vessels and fewer brown, uncoupling protein (UCP)-1-positive, adipocytes in white sc and perigonadal fat compartments and 2) white adipocyte hypertrophy. The mRNA expression of β3- adrenergic receptors, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ coactivator-1α, and UCP-1 was decreased accordingly. Moreover, PlGF -/- mice showed hyperinsulinemia. Pregnancy-associated changes were largely comparable in PlGF-/- and wild-type dams. They included expanded sc fat compartments and adipocyte hypertrophy, whereas adipose expression of key angiogenesis/adipogenesis (vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-1, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ2) and thermogenesis (β3-adrenergic receptors, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ coactivator-1α, and UCP-1) genes was down-regulated; circulating insulin levels gradually increased during pregnancy. In conclusion, reduced adipose vascularization in PlGF-/- mice impairs adaptive thermogenesis in favor of energy storage, thereby promoting insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Pregnancy adds to these changes by PlGF-independent mechanisms. Disturbed intraadipose dynamics is a novel mechanism to explain metabolic changes in late pregnancy in general and preeclamptic pregnancy in particular. Copyright © 2008 by The Endocrine Society.

Title: Relationship between the stored energy and indentation hardness of copper after compression test: Models and measurements
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Ave., Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Kazeminezhad, M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Ave., Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Utilizing the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and Vickers hardness tests, the relationship between the stored energy and indentation hardness of copper after compression test is achieved experimentally. Three dislocation models are utilized to develop the relationships between the stored energy and hardness for justifying the experimental relationship. The relationships show that the stored energy is increased by increasing the hardness, non-linearly. By comparing the models' results with the experimental data, the validity of each model at different ranges of hardness is determined. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.

Authors: Kushnir R., Ullmann A., Dayan A.
Title: Steady periodic gas flow around a well of a CAES plant
Affiliations: Department of Fluid Mechanics and Heat transfer, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kushnir, R., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Heat transfer, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel; Ullmann, A., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Heat transfer, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel; Dayan, A., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Heat transfer, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel
Abstract: The design of a Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant requires knowledge of the pressure and temperature variations within the reservoir, for expected sets of plant operation. In the current work, a closed form approximate analytical solution for the pressure variations, in porous media reservoirs, was derived for conditions of steady periodic isothermal radial gas flow. Two different expressions for the pressure variation were obtained, one as an infinite series and the other as an integral, where the latter is the computationally preferred solution. In order to evaluate the model accuracy, a finite difference numerical solution of the full non-linear problem was developed. The accuracy of the analytical solution was confirmed through, both, error analysis and comparison against the numerical calculations. The analytical solution can be used to calculate the well pressure variations and the radius of the active region around the well. Examples of calculations are provided, and a parametric study is presented to demonstrate the sensitivity of the well pressure to pertinent parameters. The model could eventually yield improved CAES plant designs. © Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 2007.

Authors: Duić N., Krajačić G., da Graça Carvalho M.
Title: RenewIslands methodology for sustainable energy and resource planning for islands
Affiliations: Department of Energy, Power Engineering and Ecology, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering and Naval Architecture, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Research Group on Energy and Sustainable Development, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Instituto Superior Técnico, Lisbon, Portugal
