Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Nexus secures tanker, first loan for Crux
Abstract: Nexus Energy Ltd, Melbourne, Australia, has secured a tanker to be converted into a floating production, storage, and offloading vessel (FPSO) and a $(Aust)50 million bank loan to launch its proposed Crux liquids project in the Browse basin off Western Australia. Vanguard Oil & Gas International is purchasing the MV Ishwari to convert into an FPSO for use at Crux. This follows a July 2007 memorandum of understanding among Nexus, Vanguard, and Viking Shipping that established an engineering design and equipment procurement program leading to the expected sanction of the Crux project during third-quarter 2008 with a production start-up of middle 2010. Design work includes a gas processing plant to be incorporated onto the topsides of the vessel and a weather-vaning turret and mooring system.

Title: General interest - Quick takes: Total to share CCS pilot results with Indonesia
Abstract: Total SA signed a deal to pass on to Indonesia the results of its CO2 capture and storage pilot project near Pau in France. The agreement gives the Indonesia Agency for the Research and Development of Energy and Mining Resources access to the main results of Total's pilot project in the Lacq basin. The project involves extracting CO2 from gases emitted by a boiler at a Lacq factor and reinjecting it 4500 m underground in an old gas field. Total plans first injection of CO2 in late 2008 and will inject a further 150,000 ton of CO2 over the following 2 yr and measure the results.

Title: Smart grid millionaire: Do you want to be one?
Authors with affiliations: Sheblé, G.B.
Abstract: Several companies are concentrating their resources for the development of a smart grid that could align the interests of electric utilities, consumers, and environmentalists through an intelligent network, the Internet. This network would control distributed resources including demand-side management, energy storage, and renewable resources. The smart grid platform would permit an operator to efficiently balance supply and demand with economic efficiency of stored energy during peak periods. A smart-grid platform would also reduce nonessential loads, optimizing existing base-load generation asset performance and relieving congestion on transmission systems. GridPoint, a smart-grid platform, claims to offer a modular, scaleable, and upgradeable architecture that enables utilities to achieve the short and long-term goals of the smart grid. GridPoint's platform offers protection from power outages, increases energy efficiency, and integrates renewable energy systems.
Index Keywords: Electric power utilization; Electric utilities; Energy management; Industrial economics; Intelligent networks; Renewable energy resources; Economic efficiency; Transmission systems; Power generation

Authors: Seó R.S., Vergani C.E., Giampaolo E.T., Pavarina A.C., Dos Santos Nunes Reis J.M., Machado A.L.
Title: Effect of disinfection by microwave irradiation on the strength of intact and relined denture bases and the water sorption and solubility of denture base and reline materials
Affiliations: Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Seó, R.S., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil; Vergani, C.E., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil; Giampaolo, E.T., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil; Pavarina, A.C., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil; Dos Santos Nunes Reis, J.M., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil; Machado, A.L., Department of Dental Materials and Prosthodontics, Araraquara Dental School, São Paulo State University, Rua Humaitá 1680, CEP-14801903, Araraquara, SP, Brazil
Abstract: This study evaluated the influence of microwave disinfection on the strength of intact and relined denture bases. Water sorption and solubility were also evaluated. A heat-polymerized acrylic resin (Lucitone 550) was used to construct 4-mm-thick (n = 40) and 2-mm-thick (n = 160) denture bases. Denture bases (2-mm) were relined with an autopolymerizing resin (Tokuso Rebase Fast, Ufi Gel Hard, Kooliner, or New Truliner). Specimens were divided into four groups (n = 10): without treatment, one or seven cycles of microwave disinfection (650 W for 6 min), and water storage at 37°C for 7 days. Specimens were vertically loaded (5 mm/min) until failure. Disc-shaped specimens (50 mm × 0.5 mm) were fabricated (n = 10) to evaluate water sorption and solubility. Data on maximum fracture load (N), deflection at fracture (mm), fracture energy (N mm), water sorption (%), and solubility (%) were analyzed by two-way analysis of variance and Student-Newman-Keuls tests (α = 0.05). One cycle of microwave disinfection decreased the deflection at fracture and fracture energy of Tokuso Rebase Fast and New Truliner specimens. The strength of denture bases microwaved daily for 7 days was similar to the strength of those immersed in water for 7 days. Microwave disinfection increased the water sorption of all materials and affected the solubility of the reline materials. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: Crosslinking; Dental polymers; Fracture; Resins; Tension
Index Keywords: Crosslinking; Fracture energy; Microwave irradiation; Polymerization; Resins; Sorption; Dental polymers; Microwave disinfection; Reline materials; Water sorption; Dental prostheses; cross linking; irradiation; microwave radiation; polymerization; solubility; sorption; strength; synthetic resin; tension; water

Title: ECS Transactions - Fundamentals of Energy Storage and Conversion
Abstract: The proceedings contain 16 papers. The topics discussed include: faradaic and non-faradaic reaction mechanisms in carbon-iodine nanocomposites electrodes asymmetric hybrid supercapacitors; oxygen reduction reaction on a Pt monolayer on Pd2Co(111) single crystal surface; transient multiscale modeling of PtxCoy catalysts degradation in PEFC environments; crucial role of low coordination sites in oxygen reduction, CO stripping, and size effect for nano-sized Pt particles; insertion of lithium into nanosized lithium titanate; electrochemical oxidation mechanism of highly oriented pyrolytic graphite in sulfuric acid solution; minimization of carbon monoxide poisoning in polymer electrolyte fuel cells using in situ PROX catalysts; and evaluation and analysis of PEM-FC performance using non-platinum cathode catalysts based on pyrolyzed Fe- and co-porphyrins - influence of a secondary heat-treatment.

Title: Newsreel: Energy consortium starts Alberta CO-2 storage project
Abstract: Enbridge is leading a consortium of 19 energy firms, including BP and ConocoPhillips, to develop CO2 storage in Alberta. The group plans to spend about $758,000 in 2009 to identify long-term storage sites in saline aquifers. Enbridge is separately considering a CO-2 pipeline and wants to increase the capacity of a line that carries oil produced in the state of North Dakota to refineries in Minnesota and elsewhere. The company is proposing a $120 million project to install more powerful pumps that can increase the flow to 162,000 bpd, up from 110,000 bpd. Enbridge has also started service on an expanded oil pipeline in North Dakota. The $78 million expansion added 30,000 bpd of capacity, bringing the system up to 110,000 bpd. Another expansion will boost total system capacity to 161,000 bpd by early 2010.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Sempra Energy is acquiring Energy South...
Abstract: Sempra Energy is acquiring EnergySouth for $0.51 billion to bolster its gas-storage operations. The deal includes 92% of Bay Gas Storage in Alabama with 11.4 bcf of working capacity and an additional 5 bcf that is under construction, with an in-service date of 2010. Plans are also in the works to expand Bay Gas capacity to 27 bcf. EnergySouth also owns 60% of a Mississippi salt-dome project with 6 bcf of storage capacity.

Title: Newsreel: Are too many gas storage facilities planned in Southeast/Gulf Region?
Abstract: A BENTEK Energy LC analysis of Southeast/Gulf region natural gas storage development reveals that 31 storage projects planned between 2008-2010, including new fields and expansions, would add 305 bcf of working gas capacity and 17.5 bcf/day of high-deliverability withdrawal capacity from multi-turn, salt-dome facilities. During the same time these storage facilities are scheduled for completion, new pipelines will bring incremental domestic production into the Southeast/Gulf region from Texas. New LNG terminals will also add to the rapid build-up of inbound capacity into the region, according to E. Russell Braziel, managing director of BENTEK Energy.

Title: Feature 1: Samsung shows strength in depth
Abstract: Production is ramping up at established South Korean yards, with Samsung Heavy Industries (SHI) reporting that it foresees building some 70 ships in 2012, compared to the 47 it turned out in 2007. Among SHI's most significant firm orders was the project to build an initial (one of four proposed) "LNG producer" hulls for FLEX LNG, featuring shipboard pre-treatment, liquefaction, storage and offloading plant. These ships will be the world's first floating LNG production units. FLEX LNG, Mitsubishi Corp, and Peak Petroleum Industries Nigeria signed a Heads of Agreement in June 2009 to develop and market the world's first floating liquefaction project offshore Nigeria jointly. The parties expect the project to produce 1.5 million ton/yr of LNG for 15 yr, with the first commercial LNG cargo planned for second half of 2011. The first of 11 ships from SHI, with three more to come from Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering, these new models are expected to spearhead long haul gas shipping to the US and Europe as the industrialized world continues its search for cleaner energy products. The Q-Max model features twin slow-speed diesel engines that are more fuel and thermally efficient than steam turbines, resulting in about a 30% reduction in overall emissions. There is also onboard cargo reliquefaction plant returning the boil-off gas that occurs when LNG is in transit to ensure full cargo delivery. Aside from the 14 Q-Max ships, 31 smaller Q-Flex-sized LNG ships were ordered from the big three Korean shipbuilders by Qatari interests and their partners.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: a joint venture between Martin Resource Management...
Abstract: A joint venture between Martin Resource Management and Energy Capital Partners is constructing Arcadia Gas Storage in north Louisiana. The salt dome, natural gas storage facility will be built in two phases over the next 3 yr and, on completion, will have 7.8 bcf of working-gas capacity.

Title: Newsreel: SG Resources Mississippi set to begin commercial service
Abstract: SGR Holdings LLC has announced that its subsidiary, SG Resources Mississippi LLC, has begun commercial service from the first of three new natural gas storage caverns at the Southern Pines Energy Center located in Greene County, MS. The FERC approved Southern Pines? natural gas tariff in March 2009. In addition, SGR has executed a new pipeline interconnect agreement with Southeast Supply Header LLC (SESH). SESH will be the fifth direct bi-directional interconnect to Southern Pines. Leaching is under way on the second cavern, which is expected to begin service next April 2009. When completed, Southern Pines will provide 24 bcf of storage in three caverns and be capable of supporting natural gas withdrawal rates of up to 1.8 bcf/day and injection rates of up to 0.9 bcf/day.

Title: PRCI research program to include work on ethanol
Abstract: Pipeline Research Council International Inc (PRCI) announced its 2008 research program, noting that member contributions of $7 million continue a 5-yr trend of increasing research spending. Research programs in which PRCI is currently engaged now total more than $20 million. The membership of PRCI has taken a strong leadership position for the past 55 yr in assuring that the energy pipeline industry is supported by a world-class research program. The 2008 program continues that legacy and will include research that is vital to the safe and efficient design, construction and operation of pipeline systems world wide. The program includes ethanol transportation research focused on the technical and operational issues associated with delivering a promising source of energy to consumers in a safe, cost-effective and environmentally sound manner. The 2008 program will also include mechanical damage, design and construction, integrity management, compressor and pump stations, measurement, and underground storage.

Title: Energy policy: CO2 cuts: The task is spelt out
Abstract: Global warming is again high on the agenda of the leaders of the group of eight main industrialized countries, as they meet in Japan in July 2008. Leaders are expected to come under pressure from their Japanese hosts to set a target to reduce CO2 emissions by 50% by 2050. Achieving this would require the marshalling of extensive technological resources at a very high cost, perhaps $45 trillion would be needed for the development of relevant infrastructure, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA) in its Energy Technology Perspectives 2008 report. The IEA believes that if the world pursues only the policies in place to date in a business-as-usual situation, CO2 emissions would rise by 130% and oil demand would increase by 70% by 2050. It would also take to achieve a 50% cut in CO2 emissions by 2050 and concludes a radical change in the energy mix of industrialized countries must begin immediately. To realize such, the IEA feels that renewables, nuclear power, and carbon capture and storage must be deployed on a massive scale and carbon-free transport developed. It will also be necessary to highlight the widespread adoption of near-zero-emissions buildings and, in one possible situation, the introduction of nearly 1 billion electric or hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles to the world's transport fleet to replace oil-powered vehicles.

Title: News in brief: North America: Canada: Private-equity firm Riverstone Holdings...
Abstract: Riverstone Holdings has agreed to acquire Gibson Energy Holdings from Hunting for $1 billion. Gibson is a midstream energy company in Canada that has 11 terminals, 290 mi of pipeline, 3.4 million bbl of crude storage capacity, and 1180 truck trailers for hauling. Riverstone Holdings has agreed to acquire Gibson Energy Holdings from Hunting for $1 billion. Gibson is a midstream energy company in Canada that has 11 terminals, 290 mi of pipeline, 3.4 million bbl of crude storage capacity, and 1180 truck trailers for hauling.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: The first phase of the Rockies Express gas pipeline...
Abstract: The first phase of the Rockies Express gas pipeline has started operation. The 713 mi link, a joint venture of Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, Sempra Pipelines and Storage and ConocoPhillips, carries up to 1.5 bcf/day from Colorado to Missouri.

Title: UAE: $460-million in contracts for Abu Dhabi-Fujairah pipeline
Abstract: Sumitomo, Salzgitter Mannesmann International, and Jindal Group of India have been awarded by International Petroleum Investment Co contracts worth $460 million to supply pipes for a domestic crude oil export line linking the UAE's emirates of Abu Dhabi and Fujairah. Initial delivery of the 48-in. dia pipe is expected in July 2008. Abu Dhabi, the largest UAE sheikdom, plans to build the 360-km oil export pipeline to transport up to 1.5 million bpd of crude to Fujairah to by-pass the Strait of Hormuz. About 17 million bpd of crude oil, or 20% of global consumption, are being shipped through the tanker route every day, and oil prices have risen over the past 2 yr partly on fears Iran could block exports from the region through Hormuz if tensions with the US escalate. Meanwhile, IPIC, which manages global energy investments in excess of $10 billion for the Abu Dhabi government, has appointed Worley Parsons Ltd to carry out the front-end engineering design on the so-called Abu Dhabi crude oil pipeline, or Adcop, project. The Adcop project, being fast-tracked for completion in 2009, will involve building storage and terminal facilities for the crude export from Fujairah, and the crude oil will be sourced from the onshore Habshan field in Abu Dhabi.

Title: News in brief: North America: Genera: Cardinal Gas Storage Partners...
Abstract: Cardinal Gas Storage Partners, a joint venture between Energy Capital Partners and Martin Resource Management, has acquired two storage development projects in Louisiana from CenterPoint Energy Gas Transmission. The Perryville Gas Storage salt dome project, which offers up to 22.5 bcf of storage capacity, began operating in June 2008. The Cadeville Gas Storage project, which is scheduled to begin operating in 2011, is a depleted reservoir development expected to have up to 16.5 bcf of gas capacity.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Cheniere Energy has completed the first phase...
Abstract: Cheniere Energy has completed the first phase of its Sabine Pass LNG receiving terminal and interconnecting Creole Trail Pipeline in Cameron Parish, LA. The first phase has 2.6 bcf/day of send-out capacity and 10 bcf of storage capacity.

Title: News: North America: Shell joints international research on carbon storage in Canada
Abstract: Shell Canda Ltd recently signed on as a co-sponsor of the International Energy Agency Greenhouse Gas Weyburn-Midale CO2 Monitoring and Storage Project in Saskatchawan, Canada. The Weyburn-Midale CO2 Project is one of the world's three largest in-field carbon storage research projects, and the largest CO2 EOR project on land. In its final phase, the $80 million international study is investigating long-term geological storage of man-made CO2 - used worldwide to increase oil production ? in mature oil reservoirs. The Project researches the geological storage of CO2 at the sites of the commercial EOR operations by EnCana Corp and Apache Canada Ltd in Saskatchewan, Western Canada. In this final phase, the technical component of the project will include work on site characterization, monitoring, and verification, wellbore integrity and risk assessment.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Market Hub Partners Holding...
Abstract: Market Hub Partners Holding, a joint venture of Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners, is adding a fourth cavern to its Moss Bluff high-deliverability salt cavern gas-storage facility in Liberty County, adding about 6.5 billion cu ft of working capacity to the facility. Construction is expected to be completed in mid-2011.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: An El Paso subsidiary will acquire...
Abstract: An El Paso subsidiary will acquire a 50% stake in the Gulf LNG Clean Energy Project, a planned import terminal in Pascagoula, MS, for an undisclosed amount. The El Paso unit will manage the construction and operation of the $1.1 billion facility, which includes the construction of two storage tanks with a combined capacity of 6.6 bcf, 10 vaporizers, and 5 mi of 36-in. pipeline. The plant should be in service by late 2011.

Title: News in brief: Western Europe: United Kingdom: Local Star Energy plans to develop...
Abstract: Local Star Energy plans to develop the decommissioned Esmond and Gordon gasfields as a gas storage facility with a capacity of 145 bcf, following a positive feasibility study carried out by Amec. The firm exercised its option to take over as operator and to raise its interest in the fields to 50%, with EnCore holding the other 50%. The development is estimated to cost $2.35 billion, excluding cushion-gas, and will call for two platforms and a 200-km, 42-in. pipeline to Bacton.

Title: Business update: Plants and projects: Eastman liscences reduced-sulfur technology to hydrogen energy international
Abstract: Eastman Chemical Co will license its reduced-sulfur start-up technology to Hydrogen Energy International. Eastman's patented technology uses a sulfur-free fuel to mitigate sulfur emissions during operational start-ups of gasification plants using coal, oil, petroleum coke, or other sulfur-containing feedstocks. The licensing agreement is part of Hydrogen Energy's plan to develop a commercial project in California that generates low-carbon hydrogen power from an integrated gasification combined cycle system with carbon capture and storage. Low-carbon hydrogen fuel is produced through the conversion of fossil fuels in combination with CO2 capture and geological sequestration, for example using CO2 in EOR.

Title: Government news: FERC approves first U.S. LNG project
Abstract: FERC approved a proposal by Broadwater Energy LLC to construct and operate the first floating terminal for the storage and delivery of LNG in the US. The project, which would delver up to 1.25 bcf/day of natural gas, calls for eight LNG storage tanks capable of storing the equivalent of 8 bcf of regasified LNG, a regasification plant, and a 21.7-mi pipeline extending from the LNG terminal to a subsea interconnection that will bring the gas onshore.

Title: Mexico: 10-year, $400-million, maintenance contract
Abstract: Pemex has awarded Energy Maintenance Services Group (EMS) and its wholly-owned subsidiary EMS Energy Services Mexico a 10-yr, $400-million contract to provide pipeline maintenance and associated services. The contract starts January 2008 and will employ ∼ 300 individuals to provide pipeline maintenance services across ∼ 2000 km of pipelines. EMS will provide services to ensure the reliability of Pemex' hydrocarbons pipeline system in the states of Tabasco, Veracruz, Chiapas, and Oaxaca. The system includes 93 pipelines totaling 1775km in length that are either operational or temporarily out of service, plus 22 pipelines totaling 325 km in length that are out of operation, as well as pumping and storage. In total, the pipelines transport 1.79 million bpd.

Title: Projects: West Virginia expansion announced
Abstract: NiSource Inc unit Columbia Gas Transmission Corp and MarkWest Energy Partners LP are planning to provide new gathering and processing services near Columbia Gas' Cobb aggregation system in Kanawha, Jackson, and Roane counties (WV). The expansion includes MarkWest's expansion of its Cobb gas plant, which will increase the total processing capacity to ≈ 70 million cu ft/day by middle-2009. The NGL recovered at the Cobb gas processing plant will continue to be fractionated at MarkWest's Siloam fractionation, marketing, and storage complex, which is in the final stages of a significant expansion. The expansion also would include Columbia adding horsepower to its existing Cobb compressor station and installing new field gathering and compression facilities to bring new gas volumes to the Cobb gas processing plant.

Title: Newsreel: PSE completes jackson prairie natural gas storage expansion
Abstract: Puget Sound Energy has finished a $44 million, 18-mo expansion effort at the Pacific Northwest's largest natural gas storage reservoir, enabling the Lewis County facility to meet one-fourth of the region's peak wintertime demand for natural gas. The completion allows the Jackson Prairie Underground Natural Gas Storage facility to accommodate the peak daily natural gas demand of 1.2 million homes across the Northwest, which represents a 35% increase in the facility's natural gas withdrawal capacity - from 850 million cu ft/day to 1.15 bcf/day. The expansion increases by 10% the total amount of natural gas available on a peak-usage day - from natural gas transportation pipelines and from storage - to the region's utilities. In addition to boosting Jackson Prairie's natural gas-withdrawal capacity, PSE has since 2002 been steadily increasing the underground facility's total storage capacity. The target is a 34% increase in storage of deliverable gas - to nearly 25 bcf - by 2012.

Title: Newsreel: Energy Commission OKs Florida Natural Gas Storage Unit
Abstract: Floridian Natural Gas Storage has received the go-ahead to construct a $600 million natural gas storage facility on a former Superfund cleanup site in Florida's Martin County. The facility would be capable of holding 8 bcf and could help utilities maintain the power grid when hurricanes disrupt production, processing, and transmission operations in the Gulf of Mexico.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners has completed...
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners has completed several expansion projects representing a total investment of more than $0.5 billion in terminal facilities at the Houston Ship Channel; New York Harbor; Argo, IL; Newport News, VA; Columbus, MS; and Edmonton, Alberta. The expansions have increased the company's total liquids storage capacity in its terminals business segment from 47.5 to about 51.5 million bbl and also boosted bulk throughput.

Title: Australasia; CSIRO's UltraBattery goes commercial
Abstract: CSIRO's long-life, increased-power UltraBattery is now a commercial reality. The hydro-electric vehicle (HEV) and renewable energy storage system has started commercial production in Japan and a deal is now agreed for manufacture and distribution in the Americas. The UltraBattery has a lifecycle that is at least four times longer and produces 50% more power than conventional battery systems. It is also ∼ 70% cheaper than the batteries currently used in HEV.

Title: Projects: Leaf River Energy's storage facility gains FERC certificate
Abstract: FERC awarded Leaf River Energy Center LLC a Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity authorizing development and operation of a salt dome natural gas storage facility and associated pipeline infrastructure in Mississippi. The storage facility will consist of caverns that will be created in two salt domes situated on > 400 acres in Smith and Jasper Counties, MS. When completed, the facility will provide up to 32 bcf of working gas capacity. The 43-mi pipeline header system associated with the facility will stretch between Smith, Jasper, and Clarke counties (MS) and interconnect with Southern Natural, Gulf South, Transco, Tennessee, Destin, and the proposed Kinder Morgan Express Pipelines. The facility will be able to inject up to 1 bcf/day and withdraw up to 2.5 bcf/day across the facility and is expected to be in service by the summer of 2010.

Authors: Benth F.E., Benth J.Š., Koekebakker S.
Title: Stochastic modeling of electricity and related markets
Source title: Stochastic Modeling of Electricity and Related Markets
Affiliations: University of Oslo, Norway; University of Agder, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Benth, F.E., University of Oslo, Norway; Benth, J.Š., University of Oslo, Norway; Koekebakker, S., University of Agder, Norway
Abstract: The markets for electricity, gas and temperature have distinctive features, which provide the focus for countless studies. For instance, electricity and gas prices may soar several magnitudes above their normal levels within a short time due to imbalances in supply and demand, yielding what is known as spikes in the spot prices. The markets are also largely influenced by seasons, since power demand for heating and cooling varies over the year. The incompleteness of the markets, due to nonstorability of electricity and temperature as well as limited storage capacity of gas, makes spot-forward hedging impossible. Moreover, futures contracts are typically settled over a time period rather than at a fixed date. All these aspects of the markets create new challenges when analyzing price dynamics of spot, futures and other derivatives. This book provides a concise and rigorous treatment on the stochastic modeling of energy markets. Ornstein–Uhlenbeck processes are described as the basic modeling tool for spot price dynamics, where innovations are driven by time-inhomogeneous jump processes. Temperature futures are studied based on a continuous higher-order autoregressive model for the temperature dynamics. The theory presented here pays special attention to the seasonality of volatility and the Samuelson effect. Empirical studies using data from electricity, temperature and gas markets are given to link theory to practice. © 2008 by World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd. All rights reserved.

Title: Proceedings of the 4th Workshop on Hot Topics in System Dependability, HotDep 2008
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Workshop on Hot Topics in System Dependability, HotDep 2008
Abstract: The proceedings contain 11 papers. The topics discussed include: consistability: describing usually consistent systems; toward quantifying system manageability; reverse-engineering drivers for safety and portability; deprogramming large software systems; a spin-up saved is energy earned: achieving power-efficient, erasure-coded storage; Byzantium: byzantine-fault-tolerant database replication providing snapshot isolation; pretty good packet authentication; dependable self-hosting distributed systems using constraints; spread-spectrum computation; 'otherworld': giving applications a chance to survive os kernel crashes; and deprogramming large software systems.

Title: Workshop on Power Aware Computing and Systems, HotPower 2008
Source title: Workshop on Power Aware Computing and Systems, HotPower 2008
Abstract: The proceedings contain 16 papers. The topics discussed include: empirical analysis on energy efficiency of flash-based SSDs; energy aware consolidation for cloud computing; augmenting RAID with an SSD for energy relief; workload decomposition for power efficient storage systems; reducing data center energy consumption via coordinated cooling and load management; greening the switch; hot data centers vs. cool peers; a comparison of high-level full-system power models; run-time energy consumption estimation based on workload in server systems; memory-aware scheduling for energy efficiency on multicore processors; and on the impact of disk scrubbing on energy savings.

Authors: Shogenova A., Sliaupa S., Shogenov K., Sliaupiene R., Vaher R., Zabele A.
Title: Carbon dioxide geological storage potential of the baltic sedimentary basin
Source title: Saint Petersburg 2008: Geosciences - From New Ideas to New Discoveries
Affiliations: Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Institute of Geology and Geography, Lithuania; Latvian University, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Shogenova, A., Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Sliaupa, S., Institute of Geology and Geography, Lithuania; Shogenov, K., Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Sliaupiene, R., Institute of Geology and Geography, Lithuania; Vaher, R., Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Zabele, A., Latvian University, Latvia
Abstract: CO2 geological storage opportunities in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are studied within the framework of EU GEOCAPACITY and CO 2NET EAST projects supported by EC FP6. The structure of the energy sector and geological conditions are different in these countries. CO 2 emissions are the highest in Estonia owing to the use of the oil shale for energy production. The three Baltic States are located within the Baltic sedimentary basin, the thickness of which varies from 100 m in NE Estonia up to 1900 m in SW Latvia and 2300 m in western Lithuania. The most prospective formation for the geological storage of CO2 is the Cambrian reservoir, including 15 large structures in Latvia that can store more than 300 Mt of CO2. The tightness of structures is evidenced by 40 years of successful operation of the Inchukalins Underground Gas Storage (UGS). Geological conditions are unfavorable for CO2 storage in Estonia. An option of transporting CO2 from Estonia via pipelines to one of the Latvian storage structures could be considered. In Lithuania the capacity of CO2 storage in Cambrian and Devonian structures as well as in oil fields is negligible, but solubility and mineral CO2 trapping is a long-term option.
Index Keywords: Oil fields; Sedimentology; Settling tanks; Underground gas storage; Carbon dioxide geological storage; Co2 geological storages; Energy productions; Geological conditions; Geological storage; Large structures; Sedimentary basin; Storage structures; Carbon dioxide

Title: LHeC ring-ring option
Source title: DIS 2008 - Proceedings of the 16th International Workshop on Deep-Inelastic Scattering and Related Topics
Affiliations: CERN-AB, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Burkhardt, H., CERN-AB, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The LHeC aims at the generation of hadron-lepton collisions with center of mass energies in the TeV scale and luminosities of the order of 10 32-1033 cm-2sec-1by taking advantage of the existing LHC 7 TeV proton ring and adding a high energy electron ac- celerator. This paper presents technical considerations and potential parameter choices for such a machine and outlines some of the challenges arising when an electron storage ring based option, constructed within the existing infrastructure of the LHC, is chosen.
Index Keywords: Elementary particles; Inelastic scattering; Storage rings; Center-of-mass energies; Electron storage ring; High-energy electron; Potential parameters; Tellurium compounds

Title: Lunar RFC reliability testing for assured mission success
Affiliations: NASA Glenn Research Center
Authors with affiliations: Bents, D.J., NASA Glenn Research Center
Abstract: NASA's Constellation program has selected the closed cycle hydrogen oxygen Polymer Electrolyte Membrane (PEM) regenerative Fuel Cell (RFC) as its baseline solar energy storage system for the lunar outpost and manned rover vehicles. Since the outpost and manned rovers are "human-rated", these energy storage systems will have to be of proven reliability exceeding 99 percent over the length of the mission. Because of the low (TRL=5) development state of the closed cycle hydrogen oxygen PEM RFC at present, and because there is no equivalent technology base in the commercial sector from which to draw or infer reliability information from, NASA will have to spend significant resources developing this technology from TRL 5 to TRL 9, and will have to embark upon an ambitious reliability development program to make this technology ready for a manned mission. Because NASA would be the first user of this new technology, NASA will likely have to bear all the costs associated with its development. When well-known reliability estimation techniques are applied to the hydrogen oxygen RFC to determine the amount of testing that will be required to assure RFC unit reliability over life of the mission, the analysis indicates the reliability testing phase by itself will take at least 2 yr, and could take up to 6 yr depending on the number of QA units that are built and tested and the individual unit reliability that is desired. The cost and schedule impacts of reliability development need to be considered in NASA's Exploration Technology Development Program (ETDP) plans, since life cycle testing to build meaningful reliability data is the only way to assure "return to the moon, this time to stay, then on to Mars" mission success. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Hydrogen storage; Life cycle; Moon; NASA; Oxygen; Polyelectrolytes; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC); Regenerative fuel cells; Software testing; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Development programs; Energy storage systems; Exploration technologies; Life cycle testing; Polymer electrolyte membranes; Reliability estimation; Reliability information; Reliability testing; Reliability analysis

Authors: Shaddock D.M., Knobloch A.J., Bansal S., Kapusta C., Cho J., Schoeller H.
Title: Polyimide flex circuitry for >200C
Affiliations: GE Global Research Center; SUNY-Binghamton
Authors with affiliations: Shaddock, D.M., GE Global Research Center; Knobloch, A.J., GE Global Research Center; Bansal, S., GE Global Research Center; Kapusta, C., GE Global Research Center; Cho, J., SUNY-Binghamton; Schoeller, H., SUNY-Binghamton
Abstract: This Department of Energy funded study represents the first significant investigation of polyimide flex as a substrate material for high temperature (>200°C) electronics packaging for downhole oil and gas exploration. This program examined at three key areas of package development: conductor adhesion to flex, through hole via reliability in flex, and high temperature interconnect methods for passive devices on flex. High temperature storage testing of different adhesion layers to flex was performed at 200 and 250°C in air and nitrogen for as long as 1000 hrs. Multiple adhesion materials and thicknesses were evaluated by measuring the peel strength of copper traces to polyimide. A Cr adhesion layer was selected due to its ability to maintain high peel strength during the high temperature storage testing. Thermal cycling of through hole vias between room temperature and 250°C for greater than 1200 cycles showed little degradation. Thermal cycling was also performed on passive components attached to flex using four high temperature solders. Results up to 277 cycles is reported. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Ability testing; Electronics packaging; Petroleum prospecting; Polyimides; Soldering alloys; Substrates; Thermal cycling; Timing circuits; Department of Energy; High temperature; High temperature solders; High temperature storage; Oil and gas exploration; Package development; Substrate material; Through-hole vias; Adhesion

Authors: Du H.Y.I., Fang X., Chen J.-S., Moss K.D., Prescott W.C.
Title: Modeling and simulation of torsional vibration of the compliant sprocket in balance chain drive systems
Affiliations: General Motors Corporation; LMS International; GMPT Engine Analysis Structure and Dynamics, 248-857-4568
Authors with affiliations: Du, H.Y.I., General Motors Corporation, GMPT Engine Analysis Structure and Dynamics, 248-857-4568; Fang, X., General Motors Corporation; Chen, J.-S., General Motors Corporation; Moss, K.D., LMS International; Prescott, W.C., LMS International
Abstract: The work presented in this paper outlines the development of a simulation model to aid in the design and development of a compliant sprocket for balancer drives. A design with dual-mass flywheel and a crank-mounted compliant chain sprocket greatly reduces interior noise levels due to chain meshing. However, experimental observations showed the compliant sprocket can enter into resonance and generate excessive vibration energy during startup. Special features are incorporated into the compliant sprocket design to absorb and dissipate this energy. Additional damper spring rate, high hysteresis and large motion angle that overlap the driving range may solve the problem during engine start-up period. This work develops a simulation model to help interpret the measured data and rank the effectiveness of the design alternatives. A Multibody dynamics system (MBS) model of the balancer chain drive has been developed, validated, and used to investigate the chain noise. This model includes a cranktrain system coupled to a full balancer drive system that includes the chain drive, balance shafts, and water pump. The nonlinear stiffness and damping effects of the baseline compliant crank chain sprocket and its design iterations are added to the model to understand the basic characteristics and find an optimal setup for the engine start-up period. New MBS solver methodologies were implemented and the subsequent productivity increases are quantified. For subjective noise assessment, simulations of a solid sprocket versus compliant sprocket balancer drive were carried out and compared for certain operating engine speed. © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Automobile transmissions; Digital storage; Engines; Mechanical drives; Powertrains; Solid lubricants; Sprockets; Vibrations (mechanical); Wheels; Basic characteristics; Chain-drive systems; Design alternatives; Design and Development; Model and simulation; Non-linear stiffness; Productivity increase; Torsional vibration; Chains

Title: Energy generating suspension system for commercial vehicles
Affiliations: Ashok Leyland Limited
Authors with affiliations: Shaiju, M.B., Ashok Leyland Limited; Mitra, M., Ashok Leyland Limited
Abstract: Fuel consumption has been a core consideration since the beginning of the transportation era. These are reasons related to our environment, and to economics. In the competitive truck industry fuel consumption is an important sales argument, since customers on an average drive their trucks for distances of 150 000 km per year, which means that fuel becomes a large part of the lifetime cost for a vehicle. Existing braking system design in commercial vehicles are basically air assisted, which utilizes the compressed air from reservoir, which is being replenished based on requirement by a positive displacement compressor, generally driven directly by vehicle power pack. In this paper, an effort has been made to partially use the energy stored in the springs (induced due to road undulations) for compressed air generation through a single acting positive displacement pump. The system design and its interface are done considering the actual measured data on a 16T Goods Vehicle at various road and road traffic conditions, namely, the in-city cycle, highway cycle and off-road cycle for both laden and un-laden applications. The preliminary analysis of the data shows a positive indication of availability of simple harmonic displacements after re-sampling of data. The re-sampling has been done using macros developed in Microsoft Excel® and the system response is developed based on the order of re-sampling. It can be strongly inferred from the acquired data that this novel design has a potential to extract road energy and support conventional braking system of commercial vehicles. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Automobile suspensions; Automotive engineering; Compressed air; Digital storage; Fuels; Magnetic levitation vehicles; Off road vehicles; Pressure vessels; Roads and streets; Suspensions (components); Systems analysis; Trucks; Harmonic displacement; Microsoft excel; Positive displacement; Positive displacement pumps; Preliminary analysis; Suspension system; System response; Truck industry; Commercial vehicles

Authors: Da Silva A.H.M.D.F.T., De Oliveira Carvalho L., De Melo T.C.C., Frank M.H.T., Dos Reis P.F.I., Villalobos P.R.
Title: An overview of hydrogen fuel for vehicular application
Affiliations: Petrobras/CENPES/Products Performance in Engines Department; Petrobras/CENPES/Renewable Energy Department
Authors with affiliations: Da Silva, A.H.M.D.F.T., Petrobras/CENPES/Products Performance in Engines Department; De Oliveira Carvalho, L., Petrobras/CENPES/Products Performance in Engines Department; De Melo, T.C.C., Petrobras/CENPES/Products Performance in Engines Department; Frank, M.H.T., Petrobras/CENPES/Renewable Energy Department; Dos Reis, P.F.I., Petrobras/CENPES/Renewable Energy Department; Villalobos, P.R., Petrobras/CENPES/Renewable Energy Department
Abstract: Hydrogen is considered one of the cleanest solutions for sustainable mobility. This paper presents an overview of some of these applications, such as internal combustion engines, fuel cell application and also blends of hydrogen and natural gas. This paper addresses questions regarding hydrogen properties such as net heating value, flame speed, power density, range of flammability and ignition energy. Also, the paper will draw a comparison between H2 and fossil and biofuels, such as ethanol. Questions regarding storage conditions, emissions levels, Internal Combustion Engine (ICE) air/fuel ratio among others are expected to be covered as well. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Fuel cells; Internal combustion engines; Air/fuel ratio; Fuel cell application; Hydrogen properties; Ignition energies; Power densities; Storage condition; Sustainable mobility; Vehicular applications; Combustion

Title: Optimization of hybrid kinetic energy recovery systems (KERS) for different racing circuits
Affiliations: Flybrid Systems LLP
Authors with affiliations: Cross, D., Flybrid Systems LLP
Abstract: This paper examines the factors which influence hybrid performance, and enable optimization of hybrid vehicles for different racing circuits. Mechanical flywheel based storage systems are evaluated. The process of evaluation looks through. Vehicle traction curve generation, influence of drivers style, traction limits, engine power limits, and differences between acceleration and braking traction. Vehicle kinetic energy, aero and rolling resistance losses, number of driven wheels, amount of energy able to be stored, rate of energy storage, storage and discharge efficiency, are all considered. Finally, the factors influencing system architecture are laid out, providing examples of optimized system hardware, at a variety of racing circuits. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Hybrid vehicles; Kinetics; Timing circuits; Curve generation; Discharge efficiency; Energy recovery system; Optimized system; Racing circuits; Storage systems; System architectures; Vehicle traction; Kinetic energy

Authors: Folkesson A., Neuman M., Gravesen C.
Title: Targets, constraints and rules for hybrid management in a series hybrid bus intended for commercial introduction
Affiliations: Scania, Sweden; KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Folkesson, A., Scania, Sweden, KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), Sweden; Neuman, M., Scania, Sweden, KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), Sweden; Gravesen, C., Scania, Sweden
Abstract: Most research on hybrid management for hybrid electric vehicles generally does not match the demands of industry and customers. Proposed methods normally have a simplified view of optimisation targets and are besides this also based on advanced but unrealistic optimisation methods. Crucial commercial and technical aspects as well as driving forces for decision-makers and customers are disregarded when the focus is solely on improving fuel economy and tailpipe emissions with advanced control and optimisation techniques. The present work aims to define a framework for a hybrid management strategy that is commercially realistic due to the fact that both customer demands on vehicle performance as well as industrial prerequisites and limitations in the control system and the hybrid powertrain are taken into account. The proposed strategy is defined as a set of rules for the hybrid management control system. A series hybrid city bus intended for commercial introduction with supercapacitors as energy storage is used as an example, but the conclusions apply also to other powertrain designs. The presented rule-based strategy is also used in a test fleet of series hybrid diesel-ethanol buses which will be in operation in Stockholm from the autumn 2008. © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Buses; Control systems; Decision making; Fleet operations; Fuel economy; Fuels; Powertrains; Sales; Vehicle performance; Management control system; Management strategies; Optimisation method; Optimisation techniques; Powertrain design; Rule-based strategy; Tailpipe emission; Technical aspects; Hybrid vehicles

Authors: Johnson Z., Cordova S., Abraham K.
Title: High performance lithium ion aircraft battery for DoD platforms
Affiliations: Mobile Energy Products, Inc.; E-KEM Sciences
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Z., Mobile Energy Products, Inc.; Cordova, S., Mobile Energy Products, Inc.; Abraham, K., E-KEM Sciences
Abstract: This paper describes a development project at Electro Energy designed to develop a high performance aircraft battery which will be suitable for use in many DoD aircraft platforms. The goal is to provide a safer high energy and power battery for aircraft energy storage systems. Aircraft batteries used on military aircraft battery platforms have a low reliability and require significant maintenance and as a result have significant costs associated with them beyond the initial procurement cost. It is desirable to develop state of the art aircraft batteries which have high reliability and minimal maintenance costs. Lithium ion cells can be employed to produce a lithium ion aircraft battery which will have significant advantages over the present nickel cadmium and lead acid aircraft batteries. The lithium ion battery will have higher specific energy, increased energy density, improved cycle life, and lower maintenance requirements. Prior projects with Electro Energy Inc. have shown increased low temperature performance and better capacity per unit volume and weight. The relationship between electrode parameters and the discharge performance of high rate batteries has been discussed previously in characterizing the rate capability of the LiCoO2 electrode by Abraham et al (Discharge Rate Capability of the LiCoO2 Electrode", J. Electrochem. Soc., 145, 482, 1998). The cathode material LiNi0.33Mn 0.33Co0.33O2 (NMC) has been identified as an excellent candidate for development of a robust positive electrode. NMC has the potential to provide a superior safe high rate cathode compared to LiCoO 2. The proper parameters to achieve optimum compaction for the electrode while leaving adequate porosity in the electrode structure for electrolyte penetration and wetting is also critical to the development of a high performance lithium ion aircraft battery. This development project includes a review of anodes, cathodes, electrolytes, additives, compositions and manufacturing processes in a wafer cell battery configuration to meet the performance requirements of DoD aircraft batteries. Cathode materials were evaluated from three different suppliers and particle sizes from 4 to 10 microns were tested for energy storage and power density. Investigations were conducted on the effects of particle size of the electrode materials and thickness of the electrode on rate capability. An initial design for a 28 volt module and 270 volt aircraft battery has been developed. Test data shows that it will be possible to achieve the initial technical objective of this effort which is to develop a lithium ion cell that will meet the aircraft battery requirements, including fast discharge and recharge over the DoD operating temperature range. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Anodes; Cathodes; Costs; Digital storage; Electric discharges; Electrolytes; Energy storage; Fighter aircraft; Ions; Lead acid batteries; Lithium compounds; Maintenance; Manganese compounds; Nickel compounds; Particle size; Temperature; Vehicle performance; Electrolyte penetration; Energy storage systems; High performance aircrafts; Low temperature performance; Maintenance requirement; Manufacturing process; Operating temperature ranges; Performance requirements; Lithium-ion batteries

Authors: Berland B., Lanning B., Hodgson E., Quinn G., Bue G., Trevino L.
Title: Multifunctional fiber batteries for next generation space suits
Affiliations: ITN Energy Systems, Inc.; Hamilton Sundstrand; NASA Johnson Space Center
Authors with affiliations: Berland, B., ITN Energy Systems, Inc.; Lanning, B., ITN Energy Systems, Inc.; Hodgson, E., Hamilton Sundstrand; Quinn, G., Hamilton Sundstrand; Bue, G., NASA Johnson Space Center; Trevino, L., NASA Johnson Space Center
Abstract: As next generation space suit concepts enable extravehicular activity (EVA) mission capability to extend beyond anything currently available today, revolutionary advances in life support technologies are required to achieve anticipated NASA mission profiles than may measure years in duration and require hundreds of sorties. Since most life support systems require power, increased mass and volume efficiency of the energy storage materials can have a dramatic impact on reducing the overall weight of next generation space suits. ITN Energy Systems, in collaboration with Hamilton Sundstrand and the NASA Johnson Space Center's EVA System's Team, is developing multifunctional fiber batteries to address these challenges. By depositing the battery on existing space suit materials, e.g. scrim fibers in the thermal micrometeoroid garment (TMG) layers, parasitic mass (inactive materials) is eliminated leading to effective energy densities ∼400 Wh/kg. The solid-state nature of the fiber battery also provides: Outstanding cycle life: >10,000 cycles, High rate: Near full capacity charge in ∼10 min., and Improved safety and packaging efficiency by eliminating liquid electrolytes. This paper highlights recent development of the multifunctional energy storage for EVA Systems. Advances in the performance of solid-state batteries on fiber/ribbon substrates are presented as well as design considerations for the integration of this technology into advanced EVA systems. Preliminary results are provided for an initial demonstration of the benefits of this technology by powering space suit health monitoring sensors with multifunctional energy storage devices. As wireless sensors are becoming of increased importance to NASA missions in general, this technology is expected to have wide spread application beyond the advanced EVA systems. Copyright © 2008 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fibers; Life support systems (spacecraft); Manned space flight; Martian surface analysis; NASA; Secondary batteries; Solid electrolytes; Solid state devices; Space platforms; Storage (materials); Design considerations; Extravehicular activity; Hamilton Sundstrand; Johnson Space Center; Life-support technologies; Liquid electrolytes; Mission capability; Solid state batteries; Space power generation

Authors: Olsson O., Hedman T., Sundman B., Svemar C.
Title: Geological disposal of radioactive waste - Experience from operating facilities in Sweden
Affiliations: Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Co. (SKB), Box 250, 101 24 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Olsson, O., Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Co. (SKB), Box 250, 101 24 Stockholm, Sweden; Hedman, T., Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Co. (SKB), Box 250, 101 24 Stockholm, Sweden; Sundman, B., Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Co. (SKB), Box 250, 101 24 Stockholm, Sweden; Svemar, C., Swedish Nuclear Fuel and Waste Management Co. (SKB), Box 250, 101 24 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Geological disposal has been the basis for the Swedish program for disposal of radioactive waste since its beginning in the mid-1970s. Two underground facilities have been in operation since the late 1980s. The construction of the final repository for short-lived, low- and intermediate level waste, SFR (Swedish final repository for radioactive operational waste), started in 1983, and it was put into operation in 1988. The facility is located 50 m below the sea, close to the Forsmark nuclear power plant, where the sea has a depth of ∼5 m. Low-level waste is placed in four rock vaults, each of which has a length of 160 m. Intermediate-level waste is stored in a concrete silo that has a height of 50 m and an inner diameter of 26 m. The disposal vaults are connected to the surface by two parallel access tunnels. The total disposal capacity is 63,000 m 3 , of which about one-half is currently in use. An expansion of the SFR is planned to accommodate radioactive waste from the decommissioning of the nation's power plants. Construction of the interim storage facility for spent nuclear fuel, Clab, started in 1980, and the facility was put into operation in 1985. The facility is located at the Oskarshamn nuclear power plant. The fuel assemblies are stored in water pools located in two 120-m-long rock chambers. The roof of the rock chambers is ∼30 m below the ground surface. Construction of a second storage vault has recently been completed. The Äspö Hard Rock Laboratory is an underground facility for developing and testing characterization methods and the different components of a system for deep geological disposal under realistic repository conditions. The facility reaches a depth of 460 m below the surface. After 5 yr of construction, it was put into operation in 1995. The licensing, construction, and operation of these facilities have provided valuable experience that is being used for the site characterization and design work currently in progress for the deep geological repository for spent nuclear fuel. The spent nuclear fuel will be disposed of in a repository located at depths between 400 and 700 m. The disposal concept is based on isolation of the spent fuel in copper canisters surrounded by a buffer of highly compacted bentonite placed in a borehole in granitic rock. Site investigations are currently in progress at two potential sites. This project is a major geoscientific undertaking that is planned to be completed in 2009 with the selection of one of the sites for the deep repository. © 2008 The Geological Society of America. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Final repository; Geologic disposal; Interim storage; Nuclear waste
Index Keywords: Fuel storage; Geological repositories; Geology; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Rocks; Underwater construction; Characterization methods; Deep geological disposal; Deep geological repository; Final repositories; Geologic disposal; Interim storage facilities; Intermediate level wastes; Site characterization; Radioactive waste disposal

Title: Uranium mining and milling in Romania past, present and future
Source title: Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Publication Series
Affiliations: National Commission for Nuclear Activities Control, Romania; Surveillance and Authorization Radioactive Mining Section, National Commission for Nuclear Activities Control, 14 Libertatii Boulevard, Bucharest 5, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Dumitrescu, N., National Commission for Nuclear Activities Control, Romania, Surveillance and Authorization Radioactive Mining Section, National Commission for Nuclear Activities Control, 14 Libertatii Boulevard, Bucharest 5, Romania
Abstract: In Romania, uranium mining started more than 50 years ago. In 1952 started the uranium ore mining in open pit Baita Plai by 'Sovrom Kuartit' Joint Venture Company. All the uranium ore, having one to five per cent uranium content and more than 20 000 t metal U, were shipped to the Soviet Union, to be used for Soviet military programs. The new uranium deposits in Bihor county (Avram Iancu deposit), in Banat county (Lisava and Ciudanovita deposits) and Suceava county (Crucea-Botusana deposit), were discovered by geological prospecting later on. In 1963, the uranium ore export to the Soviet Union was stopped. After this, the mining activity in those deposits continued in a more restricted manner, the whole ore production being stored at the mine entry and afterwards processed into U3O8 and diuranate ammonium (DUA). Meanwhile, in Romania, the nuclear fuel cycle, based on natural uranium, was developed, including: uranium ore mining; uranium ore processing at Feldioara Processing Plant, where the finished product is the dioxide uranium (UO2) sinterisable powder; production of heavy water at Turnu Severin Plant; production of nuclear fuel type CANDU at Pitesti Nuclear Fuel Plant; commissioning of two reactors type CANDU (Unit 1 and Unit 2) at NPP Cernavoda; and commissioning of the interim dry storage facility for nuclear spent fuel at NPP Cernavoda. Currently, the annual quantity of uranium metal in extracted ore is on the wane given the exhaustion of geological uranium ore reserves at the Baita and Crucea-Botusana deposits. The actual production of uranium ore covers a maximum of 25 per cent of the uranium needed by the two reactors type CANDU from NPP Cernavoda. However, the Uranium quantity needed for the normal life cycle of those two reactors is ensured by the U3O8 and diuranate ammonium (DUA) stocks previously produced and stored at Feldioara Processing Plant. According to nuclear energy development strategy in our country, the construction of Units 3 and 4 at NPP Cernavoda will be resumed, latest in 2009. The units will be commissioning latest in 2014. A new uranium ore deposit was identified in Tulghes close to Crucea-Botusana deposit, but the mining exploitation is under question due to difficulties in getting local community accord and environmental agreement. It this situation it is expected that at the commissioning of Units 3 and 4 at Cernavoda NPP, the uranium mining in Romania will provide a maximum of 12 per cent of the ore needed in the four CANDU units.
Index Keywords: Deposits; Economic geology; Environmental regulations; Fuel storage; Fuels; Heavy water; Life cycle; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Open pit mining; Ores; Uranium; Uranium dioxide; Geological prospecting; Joint venture company; Mining activities; Mining exploitation; Nuclear energy development; Nuclear fuel cycles; Nuclear spent fuels; Uranium ore deposit; Uranium deposits

Authors: Madryas C., Przybyła B., Szot A.
Title: Underground infrastructure of urban areas
Affiliations: Faculty of Civil Engineering, Wrocław University of Technology, Wrocław, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Madryas, C., Faculty of Civil Engineering, Wrocław University of Technology, Wrocław, Poland; Przybyła, B., Faculty of Civil Engineering, Wrocław University of Technology, Wrocław, Poland; Szot, A., Faculty of Civil Engineering, Wrocław University of Technology, Wrocław, Poland
Abstract: Underground infrastructure (traffic and railway tunnels, water and sewage ducts, garages, and subways) is essential for urbanized areas, as they fulfill an important role in the transportation of people, energy, communication and water. Underground Infrastructure of Urban Areas is a collection of papers on the design, application, and maintenance of underground and subterranean systems, with a focus on geotechnical aspects and town planning issues. The topics covered include: - Gas and potable water pipes; - Underground storage reservoirs; - Urban technical infrastructure and city management; - Drainage system infrastructures; - Micro tunnelling pipelines; - Underground garages; - Material structures; - Road tunnels. Underground Infrastructure of Urban Areas is of interest to academics, designers and builders of underground structures, manufacturers and suppliers of building materials and equipment, and to policy makers involved in managing and maintaining these structures. © 2009 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Pesticides as water pollutants
Source title: Groundwater for Sustainable Development: Problems, Perspectives and Challenges
Affiliations: Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Hussain, A., Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan; Asi, M.R., Nuclear Institute for Agriculture and Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan
Abstract: Pesticides stand out as one of the major development of modern agriculture. They are widely used on crops to increase yields, save energy and labour, and make crop production efficient and profitable. However, their use and or misuse may lead to serious water quality problems that could impair the use of water for crop and animal production or even human consumption. The impact of agricultural chemicals on surface water and ground water quality has become an issue of national importance. Fish kills, reproductive failure of birds, and acute illness in people have been all attributed to the ingestion of pesticides or exposure to pesticides usually as the result of misapplication, careless storage and careless disposal of unused pesticides and pesticide containers. In addition to potential health and environmental threats, pesticide losses from fields and contamination of non-target sites (such as surface water and ground water) represent a monetary loss to farmers. This paper reports recent data on pesticide residues in surface water, ground water and wastewater. © 2008 Taylor & Francis Group, London, UK.

Title: Environmental factors
Abstract: Our globe circles the Sun and one orbit takes a year. In addition, the Earth spins on its own axis once in 24 h and the rotation axis tilts 23.5° from the perpendicular to the Earth-Sun plane (Fig. 3.1.1). This geometry generates a strong annual cycle, especially at high latitudes. The distance between the globe and the Sun varies but is of lesser importance for the climate on the globe. On the other hand, the tilting of the rotation axis is the major factor in generating the annual cycle in the climate, a cycle that is particularly strong in the boreal zone. In summer, the day is very long; beyond the Arctic Circle we have polar day and the Sun does not set daily. The radiation energy input effects temperature variation. In winter, the days are short and beyond the polar circle we have polar night without daily sun rise. The energy input at the top of the atmosphere depends on the variation of solar radiation and the position of the Earth in the solar system, as well as the angle of the Earth’s axis with respect to the ecliptic plane. The factors related to position and orientation of the Earth affect the climate system also via gravitational influence by the Sun and other planets of the solar system. © Springer Science+Business Media B.V., 2009.
Author Keywords: Atmospheric boundary layer; Global radiation; Inertial subrange; Polar night; Soil water storage

Authors: Vesala T., Rannik Ü., Hari P.
Title: Transport
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 6400014, Finland; University of HelsinkiFI-00014, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Vesala, T., Department of Physics, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 6400014, Finland; Rannik, Ü., Department of Physics, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 6400014, Finland; Hari, P., University of HelsinkiFI-00014, Finland
Abstract: The system of the tree-atmosphere continuum is spatially large, which sets challenges for trees to be capable to transport various chemical compounds within them and to exchange compounds with the atmosphere. Transport phenomena and resulting mass flows are governed only by few fundamental physical laws giving rise to different transport mechanisms. The mutual effectiveness of different transport modes depends on the spatial scale. In a way, trees utilize effectively this frame of physical laws in their functioning and interactions with environment. By transport we especially mean the movement a certain quantity of mass or energy between the storage locations of the quantity. Storages may be apparent as sources and sinks of the quantity and unequal amounts of any entity in the storage locations lead to the concept of a non-zero gradient of the quantity. In practical terms, ecosystems store materials as mass (such as carbon, nutrients, water) and heat, and any differences in the amounts of mass and heat tend to disappear by physical mechanisms called transport phenomena. The third fundamental quantity besides mass and heat is momentum which is defined as the product of the mass and velocity of a homogenous fluid (fluid means either gas or liquid) parcel. All of these can be transported by two physically different mechanisms, which are molecular transport and bulk transport, called also convection. Transport of heat may happen also by means of a third heat transport mechanism which is electromagnetic radiation. Next we consider three transport mechanisms starting with the molecular one. © Springer Science+Business Media B.V., 2009.
Author Keywords: Eddy covariance; Free convection; Heat transport; Momentum transport; Turbulent transport

Authors: Sen F.G., Kinaci A., Aydinol M.K.
Title: Effect of alloying elements on the formation of FeTiH4: An ab initio study
Source title: NATO Science for Peace and Security Series C: Environmental Security
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, 06531, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Sen, F.G., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, 06531, Turkey; Kinaci, A., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, 06531, Turkey; Aydinol, M.K., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, 06531, Turkey
Abstract: FeTi can store 3.7 wt% hydrogen if it is synthesized in the form of FeTiH4. In the present study, candidate alloying elements were investigated that would decrease the formation energy of this hydride, using first principles calculations within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) to density functional theory (DFT). Selected alloying elements are Co, Mg, Mo, Ni, Nb, V and Zr, and they were substituted for Fe or Ti atoms separately. Their effects on the formation energy of FeTiH4 were analyzed on the basis of electronic structure. It was found that Zr, Nb, Mo and Mg substitution for Fe decreases the formation energy of the hydride considerably. Stabilization is achieved by forming stronger bonds between hydrogen atoms and rest of the Fe atoms in the structure which is facilitated by the antibonding between the hydrogen atoms and the substituted high tendency hydride forming element. © Springer Science + Business Media B.V. 2008.
Author Keywords: FeTi; First principles calculations; Hydrogen storage; Metal hydrides

Authors: Shrestha R.M., Pradhan S., Liyanage M.H.
Title: Effects of carbon tax on greenhouse gas mitigation in Thailand
Affiliations: School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, PO Box 4, Klong Luang, Pathumthani, 12120, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Shrestha, R.M., School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, PO Box 4, Klong Luang, Pathumthani, 12120, Thailand; Pradhan, S., School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, PO Box 4, Klong Luang, Pathumthani, 12120, Thailand; Liyanage, M.H., School of Environment, Resources and Development, Asian Institute of Technology, PO Box 4, Klong Luang, Pathumthani, 12120, Thailand
Abstract: This study analyses energy system development and the associated greenhouse gas emissions in Thailand under a reference case and three different carbon tax scenarios during 2013–2050 using a bottom-up cost-minimizing energy system model based on the Asia—Pacific Integrated Assessment Model (AIM/Enduse) framework. It considers the role of the renewable energy technologies as well as some emerging GHG-mitigating technologies, e.g. carbon capture and storage (CCS) in power generation, and GHG reduction in the country, and found that the power sector will play a major role in CO2 emission reduction. Under the carbon tax scenarios, most of the CO2 emission reduction (over 70%) will come from the power sector. The results also indicate the very significant potential for CO2 emission reduction through a significant change in the transport system of the country by shifting from low-occupancy personal modes of transport to electrified MRTS and railways. © 2008 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Carbon pricing; CO2 reductions; Energy systems; Low-carbon society; Policy instruments; Scenario modelling; Thailand

Authors: Battaglia A., Beck H.P., Dobson M., Gadomski S., Kordas K., Vandelli W.
Title: The Data-Logging System of the Trigger and Data Acquisition for the ATLAS Experiment at CERN
Affiliations: Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland; European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland; Institute of Nuclear Physics, Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Battaglia, A., Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland; Beck, H.P., Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland; Dobson, M., European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland; Gadomski, S., Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland, Institute of Nuclear Physics, Cracow, Poland; Kordas, K., Laboratory for High Energy Physics (LHEP), University of Bern, Switzerland; Vandelli, W., European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Abstract: The ATLAS experiment is getting ready to observe collisions between protons at a centre of mass energy of 14 TeV. These will be the highest energy collisions in a controlled environment to-date, to be provided by the Large Hadron Collider at CERN by mid 2008. The ATLAS Trigger and Data Acquisition (TDAQ) system selects events online in a three level trigger system in order to keep those events promising to unveil new physics at a budgeted rate of ∼ 200 Hz for an event size of ∼ 1.5 MB. This paper focuses on the data-logging system on the TDAQ side, the so-called “Sub-Farm Output” (SFO) system. It takes data from the third level trigger, and it streams and indexes the events into different files, according to each event’s trigger path. The data files are moved to CASTOR, the central mass storage facility at CERN. The final TDAQ data-logging system has been installed using 6 Linux PCs, holding in total 144 disks of 500 GB each, managed by three RAID controllers on each PC. The data-writing is managed in a controlled round-robin way among three independent filesystems associated to a distinct set of disks, managed by a distinct RAID controller. This novel design allows fast I/O, which together with a high speed network permits to minimize the number of SFO nodes. We report here on the functionality and performance requirements on the system, our experience with commissioning it and on the performance achieved. © 2008, IEEE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Data acquisition; data handling; disks

Title: CO2 Capture and Storage: A key carbon abatement option
Source title: CO2 Capture and Storage: A Key Carbon Abatement Option
Authors with affiliations: IEA
Abstract: Oil, coal and natural gas will remain the world's dominant sources of energy over the next decades, with resulting carbon dioxide emissions set to increase to unsustainable levels. However, technologies that help reduce CO2 emissions from fossil fuels can reverse this trend. CO2 capture and storage (CCS) is particularly promising. CCS takes CO2 from large stationary sources and stores it in deep geological layers to prevent its release into the atmosphere. Responding to a G8 Gleneagles request, this study documents progress toward the development of CCS, covering capture, transportation and storage technologies and their costs; storage capacity estimates, regional assessment of CCS potential; legal and regulatory frameworks; public awareness and outreach strategies; and financial mechanisms and international mechanisms. It also discusses the role of CCS in ambitious new energy scenarios that aim for substantial emissions reduction. This publication elaborates the potential of CCS in coal-fuelled electricity generation and estimates for capture in the industry and fuel transformation sectors. Finally, it assesses the infrastructure needed to process and transport large volumes of CO2. © OECD 2009.

Authors: Kaegi E., Cherkaoui R., Germond A.
Title: Decentralized unit commitment and dispatch for the distribution systems using intelligent agents approach
Affiliations: EPFL, Laboratoire de Réseaux Electriques, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Kaegi, E., EPFL, Laboratoire de Réseaux Electriques, Lausanne, Switzerland; Cherkaoui, R., EPFL, Laboratoire de Réseaux Electriques, Lausanne, Switzerland; Germond, A., EPFL, Laboratoire de Réseaux Electriques, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized approach for the management of distribution systems including dispersed generation. The methodology is zonal approach and multi-agent systems based. The study presented compares centralized and decentralized methods and draws conclusions about the advantages and drawbacks of each.
Author Keywords: Dispersed generation; Distributed optimization; Distribution grid; Multi-agent systems; Storage; Unit commitment and dispatch
